questions.text: A 37-year-old male patient presents to the surgical emergency with a history of peptic ulcer disease and pain in abdomen, bloating, and obstipation for 3 days. What is the next line in management? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Given scenario of history of peptic ulcer disease with acute abdomen suggests a peptic ulcer perforation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV fluids: Administering intravenous (IV) fluids is essential to address potential dehydration or peritonitis, to stabilise the patient.

 

Option B. CECT abdomen (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography of the abdomen): Performing a CECT abdomen is a diagnostic step that can help identify the cause of the patient's symptoms, such as complications related to peptic ulcer disease, including perforation or other abdominal pathologies.

 

Option C. Exploratory laparotomy: An exploratory laparotomy may be necessary if the patient's condition deteriorates or if there are signs of a surgical emergency, such as peritonitis or suspected perforation.

 

In summary, option D is correct because it covers the initial steps in managing this patient comprehensively, including addressing fluid balance (IV fluids), diagnostic imaging (CECT abdomen), and considering surgical intervention (exploratory laparotomy) if indicated by the clinical presentation and imaging findings

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Perforation of a hollow viscus is a life-threatening condition caused by the rupture of the alimentary tract.
  • This results in the leakage of enteric contents, leading to acute bacterial peritonitis.
  • Clinical features include abdominal pain and distension, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, rebound tenderness, decreased or absent bowel sounds, and guarding on palpation.
  • Investigations include estimating the white blood cell count, urea, serum electrolytes, and an erect abdominal radiograph showing free gas under the diaphragm.
  • CECT is the most sensitive investigation to detect minimal/suspected pneumoperitoneum.
  • Management includes IV fluids and exploratory laparotomy.

questions.text: Which of the following is contraindicated in a neonate with a scaphoid abdomen? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bag & Mask ventilation 

 

  • In a neonate presenting with a scaphoid abdomen, certain respiratory interventions need to be carefully considered due to the high risk of underlying conditions like congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH). 

 

This is contraindicated in neonates with a scaphoid abdomen suspected of having CDH. The use of positive pressure from bag and mask ventilation can exacerbate the displacement of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity through the diaphragmatic defect, potentially worsening respiratory distress and leading to further compromise of pulmonary function. This method of ventilation can increase the risk of pneumothorax, gastric distention, and further reduce lung volume, which is already compromised in CDH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IPPV (Intermittent Positive Pressure Ventilation): Like intubation, IPPV is used via a mechanical ventilator after intubation and can provide controlled and safe respiratory support. It is also appropriate in these scenarios to ensure that airway pressure is managed carefully to avoid exacerbating the hernia.

 

Option C. Intubation: This is the preferred method for securing the airway in a neonate with a scaphoid abdomen when CDH is suspected. Intubation allows for controlled ventilation settings, minimizes gastric distension, and helps manage the baby’s respiratory status more effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The critical point in managing a neonate with a scaphoid abdomen, particularly when a condition like CDH is suspected, involves avoiding exacerbation of the hernia through inappropriate respiratory support techniques. Opting for intubation and controlled mechanical ventilation instead of bag & mask ventilation is crucial to prevent further complications and stabilize the infant's condition. Properly securing the airway and ensuring adequate ventilation without increasing the risk of further pulmonary or gastrointestinal injury is essential in the initial management of these patients.

questions.text:
You are a primary care physician seeing a patient for a routine check-up. The patient expresses concern about colon cancer and asks about potential risk factors and preventive measures. You provide the following information: (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Right and left colon cancers can exhibit distinct behaviour.
  2. Colon cancer can have hereditary components.
  3. Colon cancer risk can be mitigated by metformin.
  4. Liver metastases are a common occurrence in colon cancer.

 

Which of the following options is/are true regarding colon cancer:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, and 4

 

All the 4 statements given are true about colon cancer.

 

  • Right and left colon cancers exhibit different characteristics, with left-sided tumors being more likely to cause obstruction due to the caliber of the bowel and consistency of stool.
  • Proximal colon cancers, or right colon cancers, are typically diagnosed later and may present with iron deficiency anemia or a mass.
  • While the majority of colorectal cancers occur sporadically, some can be hereditary and are more common in patients with a family history of the disease, like FAP and HNPCC. Genetic testing can aid in early diagnosis.
  • Metformin, a biguanide compound used to treat diabetes, has been shown to reduce the risk of colorectal cancer by disrupting cellular energy supply and inhibiting aerobic glycolysis.
  • Liver metastasis is the most frequent site of distant metastasis in colorectal cancer and occurs through hematogenous spread via the portal venous system. Tumor size and grade are risk factors. The second most common site of distant metastasis is the lung, while carcinomatosis can occur through peritoneal seeding.

questions.text: Which of these is the most common type of hernia in females? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Indirect inguinal

 

While it is commonly believed that femoral hernias are the most frequent type of hernia in females, this is not the case. The most common type of hernia in both males and females is the inguinal hernia, specifically the indirect inguinal hernia.

 

Inguinal hernias occur due to a weakness in the abdominal wall and the presence of a natural opening, the deep inguinal ring. Indirect inguinal hernias, which pass through this deep ring, are particularly common. Although femoral hernias are more commonly seen in women than in men, their overall incidence is much lower compared to inguinal hernias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct inguinal: This type of hernia is less common than indirect inguinal hernias and occurs due to weakness in the floor of the inguinal canal. It is not the most common type in females.

 

Option C. Femoral: Although more common in women than in men, femoral hernias have a much lower overall incidence compared to inguinal hernias.

 

Option D. Obturator: This is a rare type of hernia and is not commonly seen in the general population, including females.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common type of hernia in females, as in males, is the indirect inguinal hernia. Despite the misconception, femoral hernias, though more common in women than men, are less frequent overall.

questions.text: Breast cancer of size 6 x 8 cm with dimpling with invasion of Pectoralis Major and ipsilateral matted axillary nodes belongs to what TNM stage? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) T3N2M0

 

  • Tumor size > 5 cm = T3
  • Skin dimpling does not affect T stage (common misconception)
  • Invasion of pectoralis major does not affect T stage
  • Only skin ulceration, peau d'orange, or satellite nodules make it T4b
  • Ipsilateral matted axillary nodes = N2
  • No mention of distant metastasis = M0


Other Options: 

 

Option B. T4bN1M0:

 

  • Skin dimpling alone does not make it T4b
  • N1 represents mobile nodes, while the question mentions matted nodes (N2)
     

Option C. T4aN2M0:

 

  • T4a represents chest wall invasion (not including pectoralis major)
  • Invasion of pectoralis major alone does not make it T4a
     

Option D. T2N2M1:

 

  • T2 is for tumors 2-5 cm, this tumor is > 5 cm

  • No evidence of distant metastasis (M1)

     

Educational Objective:

 

  • Skin dimpling and pectoralis major invasion do not affect T stage in breast cancer TNM staging
  • T3 stage is for tumors > 5 cm
  • Matted axillary nodes represent N2 disease

choices.text: Commonly presents as an abdominal mass
Presents in children < 6 years of age
Majority of patients recover due to chemotherapy and radiotherapy
Lung metastasis is rare and seen as a late feature

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect about Wilms’ tumor? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lung metastasis is rare and seen as a late feature

 

Wilms’ tumor, also known as nephroblastoma, is a type of kidney cancer that primarily affects children, typically under the age of six. It is one of the most common pediatric solid tumors and presents with a variety of clinical features, most notably an abdominal mass.

 

  • Common Presentation: The most common presenting symptom of Wilms’ tumor is a painless abdominal mass, which may be noticed by the child's parents or during a routine physical examination. This aligns with option A, making it correct.
  • Age of Onset: Wilms’ tumor most frequently occurs in young children, particularly those under the age of six. This is well-documented in clinical practice and research, making option B correct.
  • Treatment and Prognosis: The treatment for Wilms’ tumor typically includes a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and sometimes radiotherapy. The majority of patients have a good prognosis and can recover with appropriate treatment, supporting option C as correct.
  • Lung Metastasis: Contrary to option D, lung metastasis is actually relatively common in Wilms’ tumor and often one of the first sites of metastasis. It is not rare, nor is it necessarily a late feature. Early detection and treatment of lung metastases are crucial in the management of Wilms' tumor, making this option incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Commonly presents as an abdominal mass: This is a correct statement. Wilms’ tumor typically presents as an abdominal mass, which is often the first sign that prompts further investigation.

 

Option B. Presents in children < 6 years of age: This is also correct. The majority of cases occur in children under the age of six, making this a well-recognized feature of the disease.

 

Option C. Majority of patients recover due to chemotherapy and radiotherapy: This statement is accurate as well. Advances in chemotherapy and radiotherapy have significantly improved survival rates for patients with Wilms’ tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lung metastasis in Wilms’ tumor is not rare; it is actually a common site of metastasis and often occurs early in the disease course.

choices.text: TACE is used for multinodular lesions
Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm
The incidence of HCC is increasing
NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC

questions.text: Identify the false statement out of the following: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm

 

Lenvatinib is used to treat advanced stages of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Treatment of lesions less than 3 cm is wide excision or liver transplant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TACE is used for multinodular lesions: True. TACE (Transarterial chemoembolization) combined with other treatments is used for unresectable multiple nodular and massive HCC, especially when a single nodular diameter is greater than 5 cm (intermediate or advanced HCC).

 

Option C. The incidence of HCC is increasing: True. The incidence of HCC is increasing worldwide due to the increase in HCV and HBV infections, along with lifestyle disorders like obesity.

 

Option D. NASH (Non-Alcoholic Steatohepatitis) and NAFLD (Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease) are risk factors for HCC: True. Obesity is associated with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NALD), which progresses to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) causing cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma. Thus, NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Barcelona-Clinic-Liver Cancer (BCLC) Classification is the commonly used staging system for HCC.
  • Very early HCC is treated by ablation, early HCC with a single nodule is resected, and when there are multiple nodules over 3 cm, ablation or transplantation are considered.
  • Intermediate stage HCC is treated by chemoembolization, and TACE (Trans-arterial chemoembolization) is used for multinodular lesions.
  • Advanced stages of the disease with macrovascular invasion are treated with systemic therapies. Lenvatinib and sorafenib are first-line drugs.
  • Supportive care is given at the terminal stage of the disease.

questions.text: Identify the device in the image: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PEG tube

 

The image provided shows a tray containing various instruments, including an introducer, a tube with a bolster, and a guide wire, which are characteristic of a PEG (Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrostomy) tube kit. A PEG tube is used for providing nutrition directly into the stomach in patients who cannot swallow food. The distinguishing features of a PEG tube include a retention bolster that secures the tube to the abdominal wall and an inflatable balloon at the end that helps retain the tube within the stomach. The presence of these components in the tray confirms that the  is a PEG tube. This procedure involves making a small incision in the abdomen, inserting the tube, and securing it, which is why the tray includes various tools for this process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NJ tube (Nasojejunal tube): An NJ tube is inserted through the nose and extends into the jejunum. It is typically used for feeding but does not require the surgical kit or bolster shown in the image.

 

 

Option C. NG tube (Nasogastric tube): An NG tube is a simple tube inserted through the nose into the stomach or intestine. Unlike the PEG tube, it does not involve a retention bolster or a complex insertion procedure, making it less likely to require the tools seen in the image.

 

 

Option D. Chest drain tube: A chest drain tube is used to remove air, fluid, or pus from the pleural space in the chest. It typically does not include the bolster and balloon characteristic of a PEG tube, and the tools in the image do not match those used for chest drainage procedures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The PEG tube is a specialized device used for long-term feeding directly into the stomach, identified by its retention bolster and the presence of specific tools in the insertion kit. Understanding the key components of the PEG tube kit helps differentiate it from other types of medical tubes

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of prior neck radiation for lymphoma is diagnosed with 2 x 3 cm papillary thyroid cancer. No lymph node enlargement is present. What is the treatment? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Total thyroidectomy

 

Explanation: 

 

Total thyroidectomy is now the preferred approach only for those differentiated thyroid cancers (DTCs) at higher risk for recurrence:

  • Tumor at least  4 cm 
  • Gross extrathyroidal extension 
  • Evidence of metastatic disease 
  • Radiation-induced DTC (mentioned in the history) 
  • Familial non-medullary thyroid cancer 
  • Multifocal bilateral DTC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemithyroidectomy:

 

  • History of radiation is a high-risk feature requiring total thyroidectomy
  • Hemithyroidectomy is reserved for low-risk, small unifocal tumors without risk factors

 

Option C. Hemithyroidectomy + MRND:

 

  • MRND is not indicated without clinical lymphadenopathy
  • MRND is mainly done for medullary thyroid cancer
  • Hemithyroidectomy is inadequate given the radiation history

 

Option D. Total Thyroidectomy + MRND:

 

  • No lymph node involvement noted
  • For papillary thyroid cancer without lymphadenopathy, central compartment (level VI) clearance may be done, but not MRND

 

Educational Objective: 

 

History of radiation exposure is an absolute indication for total thyroidectomy in differentiated thyroid cancer, regardless of tumor size.

choices.text: Usually symptomatic with dyspnoea, dysphagia and SVC syndrome
Chest Xray is the investigation of choice

questions.text: What is the accurate statement regarding thymoma? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most common neoplasm of thymus

 

Thymomas are indeed the most common primary tumors of the thymus. These tumors originate from the epithelial cells of the thymus, an organ located in the anterior mediastinum. While they can be associated with various systemic syndromes, particularly myasthenia gravis, they may also be asymptomatic and are sometimes discovered incidentally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Most common posterior mediastinal tumor: This statement is incorrect. Thymomas are tumors of the anterior mediastinum, not the posterior. Neurogenic tumors are the most common tumors in the posterior mediastinum.

 

Option C. Usually symptomatic with dyspnoea, dysphagia and SVC syndrome: Thymomas can be asymptomatic or they may present with symptoms due to compression of nearby structures. While they can cause symptoms like dyspnea (shortness of breath) if they compress the trachea or lungs, or symptoms of Superior Vena Cava (SVC) syndrome if they compress the SVC, these are not the most common presentations. The association with systemic syndromes like myasthenia gravis is more characteristic.

 

Option D. Chest Xray is the investigation of choice: While a chest X-ray can identify a mediastinal mass suggesting a thymoma, a computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest is usually the investigation of choice for further characterization and to evaluate the exact size, location, and any local invasion. The CT scan provides more detailed images than a simple chest X-ray.

questions.text: Following a stab injury to the chest, the following imaging finding was noted. What is the diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hemothorax

 

In this scenario, the patient has sustained a stab injury to the chest, and an X-ray has been provided as part of the diagnostic process. The X-ray described in the  reveals a white area on the affected side of the lung field.

Hemothorax: A hemothorax occurs when blood accumulates in the pleural cavity. On a chest X-ray, this condition presents as a white-out or opaque area on the affected side due to the fluid (blood) collecting in the pleural space. The clinical findings, such as hypotension (which can result from blood loss), further support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: In contrast, a pneumothorax, which is the presence of air in the pleural space, would show up on a chest X-ray as a black area (radiolucency) without lung markings, indicating air in the pleural space. This would not match the white-out appearance seen in the provided X-ray.

 

Option C. Diaphragmatic Rupture: This condition would typically present with air-fluid levels within the chest cavity if abdominal organs have herniated into the thoracic cavity. However, this is not indicated by the described X-ray findings.

 

Option D. Lung Contusion: A lung contusion would appear as a focal area of consolidation (white patch) due to localized bleeding or bruising of the lung tissue, but it would not cause a widespread white-out of the lung field.

 

Thus, the presence of a white-out on the X-ray, along with clinical signs such as hypotension, suggests the correct diagnosis is hemothorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A white-out on the chest X-ray after a chest injury, especially with accompanying hypotension, is indicative of a hemothorax, which is the accumulation of blood in the pleural space.

choices.text: Pain occurs on walking a fixed distance and is relieved by rest
Pain occurs immediately on standing and improves on bending forward
Pain is worse at night in bed and at rest
Pain occurs on taking the first step

questions.text: Which of these is true about intermittent claudication? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pain occurs on walking a fixed distance and is relieved by rest

 

Intermittent claudication characteristics:

 

  • Pain occurs after walking a predictable distance
  • Distance is relatively fixed for each patient
  • Pain is relieved by rest within minutes
  • Indicates chronic peripheral arterial disease
  • Due to inadequate blood flow during exercise

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pain occurs immediately on standing and improves on bending forward:

 

  • This describes neurogenic claudication
  • Characteristic of lumbar canal stenosis
  • Not related to vascular insufficiency

 

Option C. Pain is worse at night in bed and at rest:

 

  • This describes rest pain
  • Feature of critical limb ischemia
  • Advanced stage of peripheral arterial disease
  • Not intermittent claudication

 

Option D. Pain occurs on taking the first step:

 

  • Feature of neurogenic claudication
  • Seen in spinal canal stenosis
  • Not characteristic of vascular disease

 

Educational Objective: 


Intermittent claudication is characterized by pain occurring after walking a fixed distance and being relieved by rest, similar to angina of the legs.

choices.text: To determine sentinel lymph node involvement
To immediately confirm the definitive diagnosis in all cases

questions.text: During the surgery of breast carcinoma, a frozen section was conducted. Which of the following options is incorrect regarding this procedure? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) To immediately confirm the definitive diagnosis in all cases

 

Incorrect. While a frozen section can provide rapid results, it does not replace the need for a formal and thorough pathological examination of paraffin-embedded tissue sections. The frozen section technique can sometimes result in artifacts that make interpretation challenging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To determine sentinel lymph node involvement: Correct. A sentinel lymph node biopsy is commonly performed during breast cancer surgery, and a frozen section of the node can be examined to determine if there's cancerous involvement. If positive, complete axillary lymph node clearance can be done.

 

Option B. To assess margin positivity: Correct. During breast-conserving surgeries, the surgeon aims to remove the tumor along with a rim of normal tissue. A frozen section can be used to immediately check if the margins (edges) of the removed tissue are free of cancer cells. If cancer cells are found at the margin, additional tissue can be removed during the same procedure.

 

Option C. To evaluate metastasis: Correct. The frozen section can be used to evaluate if there's metastasis to the lymph nodes or other tissues sampled during the surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The analysis of frozen sections can assist in diagnosing nodal metastasis and identifying the involvement of sentinel lymph nodes during surgery.
  • If a positive node is detected during the procedure, the surgeon can proceed with the immediate removal of axillary lymph nodes.
  • Conversely, if the sentinel node shows no signs of tumor involvement, additional axillary dissection can be avoided.
  • In breast-conserving surgeries, frozen sections can aid in assessing tumor margins and ensuring complete removal.

questions.text: A wound was left open initially, with debridement and cleaning performed for 5 days before it was closed by sutures. What type of wound healing is this? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tertiary intention

 

Tertiary intention (delayed primary healing):

 

  • Wound initially left open
  • Allowed to develop healthy granulation tissue
  • Closure performed after controlling infection/contamination
  • Also called delayed primary closure
  • Results in better healing than secondary intention
  • Common in contaminated wounds

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Secondary intention:

 

  • Occurs when the wound is left open to heal on its own
  • No surgical closure is performed
  • Results in wider scar

 

Option C. Primary intention:

 

  • Immediate closure of clean wound edges
  • No period of open wound management
  • No delayed closure component
  • Results in thin linear scar

 

Option D. Quaternary: This is not a recognized type of wound healing

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Tertiary intention (delayed primary healing) involves initial open wound management followed by surgical closure after the development of healthy granulation tissue.

questions.text: What treatment should be avoided for a male patient in his mid-40s who was brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident, and presents with a heart rate of 120/min, respiratory rate of 30/min, and an X-ray image of his chest? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chest tube insertion

 

Given Scenario with x ray shows left sided traumatic diaphragmatic rupture with herniation of stomach. Nasogastric tube insertion, log roll, or epidural anesthesia can be done. However, intercostal drain should not be put as it would traumatic the herniated content.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The provided image displays an elevated left hemidiaphragm with stomach herniated into thorax, likely due to a diaphragmatic hernia resulting from blunt trauma in a road traffic accident.

 

  • Chest tube insertion or thoracostomy is not recommended in cases of diaphragmatic hernia and is contraindicated
  • Chest tube insertion is generally indicated for pneumothorax, hemothorax, chylothorax, pleural effusion, among others, but is contraindicated in the presence of pulmonary adhesions, pulmonary trauma, coagulopathy, and diaphragmatic hernia.
  • To insert a chest tube, the 5th intercostal space should be accessed anterior to the midaxillary line, within the triangle of safety, which is located above the level of the nipple and below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.
  • Acquired diaphragmatic hernia does not contraindicate nasogastric tube insertion, log roll, or epidural anesthesia.

choices.text: IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, assisted drainage, and MRI
IV fluids, MRI, assisted drainage, and laparotomy
IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, and assisted drainage
IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, assisted drainage, MRI, and laparotomy

questions.text: Which of the following steps are included in the management of acute necrotizing pancreatitis in a patient with large intra-abdominal fluid accumulation and pancreatic necrosis?  (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, and assisted drainage

 

MRI is not indicated in patients with acute necrotising pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct steps in the management of acute necrotizing pancreatitis include IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, and assisted drainage. Large intra-abdominal fluid accumulation and pancreatic necrosis are complications of acute pancreatitis that require immediate management.

 

Aggressive fluid resuscitation, pain control, and early nutrition are initiated, followed by contrast-enhanced computed tomography to diagnose necrosis. If infected necrosis is suspected, fine-needle aspiration is done, and the aspirate is subjected to Gram staining and culture sensitivity. IV antibiotics are started with carbapenem as the first-choice drug.

 

The step-up approach, which includes percutaneous drainage followed by minimally invasive video-assisted retroperitoneal debridement, is adopted for definitive management. Hence, the correct option is C) IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, and assisted drainage.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Due to increasing mammography, there occurs over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma
  2. Colon cancer screening is done by digital rectal examination
  3. Oral cancer screening is done by visual inspection
  4. Cervix cancer screening is done by a pap smear
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4

 

Statements 1, 3 and 4 are true.

 

1. Due to increasing mammography, there occurs over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma: This is true. Mammography is an essential tool in the early detection of breast cancer, but it has been associated with over-diagnosis. As a result, some women might receive unnecessary treatment for non-life-threatening tumors.

 

2. Oral cancer screening is done by visual inspection: This is true. Visual inspection of the oral cavity can detect precancerous lesions or early signs of oral cancer. Regular dental check-ups often include a visual check for signs of oral cancer.

 

3. Cervix cancer screening is done by a pap smear: This is true. A Pap smear (or Pap test) is a procedure to test for cervical cancer in women. The test involves collecting cells from the cervix to be examined under a microscope to detect abnormalities that can turn into cervical cancer.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Colon cancer screening is done by digital rectal examination: This statement is not entirely accurate. While a digital rectal examination (DRE) can detect some abnormalities or tumors in the rectum, it is not the primary method for colon cancer screening. The primary methods for colon cancer screening include fecal occult blood testing, sigmoidoscopy, and colonoscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Screening for common cancers using relatively non-invasive tests is expected to lead to early diagnosis, allow more conservative surgical therapies with decreased morbidity, and potentially improve surgical cure rates and overall survival rates.
  2. Current American Cancer Society guidelines advocate colon cancer screening for the average-risk population beginning at age 50 years. Recommended procedures include yearly fecal occult blood testing (FOBT)/fecal immunohistochemical testing (FIT), flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years, or FOBT/FIT and flexible sigmoidoscopy.
  3. Visual inspection of the oral cavity has been widely used for screening oral cancer. The target population for oral cancer screening includes those aged 30 years and older who use tobacco and/or alcohol. Advantages of visual inspection include its feasibility, safety, acceptability, accuracy to detect oral precancerous and cancerous lesions, and efficacy and cost-effectiveness in reducing oral cancer mortality.
  4. Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. Screening should begin at age 21 years. For women aged between 21-29 years, screening should be done every 3 years with Pap smear examination. For women aged between 30-65 years, screening should be done every 5 years with both HPV and the Pap co-test.
  5. Using mammography as a routine screening tool in women has been reported to reduce mortality from breast cancer. The United Kingdom recently established an independent expert panel to estimate the benefits and harms associated with screening women in its national screening program. The panel estimated that breast screening resulted in a 20% reduction in breast cancer mortality. The panel also noted over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma but concluded that breast screening confers significant benefits and should be continued.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with Graves' disease with eye signs and enlarged thyroid is scheduled for a total thyroidectomy. What medication can be administered in the preoperative period to minimize intraoperative bleeding in this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Potassium iodide

 

Potassium iodide, which can be given 10 days before the surgery to reduce intraoperative bleeding during total thyroidectomy. This is because iodide alone produces transient remission and may reduce vascularity, thereby marginally improving safety.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can be used to prepare the patient for surgery by inhibiting the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 and causing beta-adrenergic blockade. However, it is not specifically used to reduce intraoperative bleeding during thyroidectomy. It is beneficial in thyroid storm.

 

Option C. Propylthiouracil: Propylthiouracil is an antithyroid drug that inhibits thyroid synthesis and peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. It is used to render the patient euthyroid before surgery, but it is not specifically used to reduce intraoperative bleeding.

 

Option D. Betamethasone: Betamethasone is a glucocorticoid that reduces the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. However, it is not used preoperatively in thyroidectomy to reduce intraoperative bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Graves' disease is an autoimmune disorder that results in an overactive thyroid gland, known as hyperthyroidism. In this condition, the immune system attacks the thyroid gland, causing it to produce more thyroid hormone than the body needs. As a result, the thyroid gland becomes hyperactive, leading to various symptoms associated with hyperthyroidism. Graves' disease is the most prevalent cause of hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient undergoes an appendicectomy procedure. Two days later, she complains of severe abdominal pain and is found to have a collection of blood in the abdomen on examination. On exploration, it is discovered that a particular artery should have been ligated during the surgery to prevent this complication. Which of the following arteries should have been ligated during the appendicectomy procedure to prevent postoperative hemorrhage in this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ileocolic artery

 

The ileocolic artery is a branch of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) that supplies blood to the appendix and the cecum. During an appendicectomy procedure, it is crucial to identify and ligate the appendicular branch of ileocolic artery to prevent postoperative hemorrhage. Failure to do so can result in bleeding complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right colic artery: The right colic artery is another branch of the SMA that supplies blood to the ascending colon and the right side of the transverse colon. Ligating the right colic artery is not a standard part of an appendicectomy procedure.

 

Option C. Superior rectal artery: The superior rectal artery is a branch of the inferior mesenteric artery and supplies blood to the rectum. It is not directly related to an appendicectomy procedure.

 

Option D. Superior mesenteric artery: The superior mesenteric artery is a major blood vessel that supplies blood to various parts of the small intestine, including the jejunum and ileum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During the removal of the appendix, the inferior branch of the ileocolic artery needs to be ligated at the base of the appendix to prevent postoperative hemorrhage. The appendicular artery typically arises directly from the ileocolic artery and supplies the appendix through multiple small branches. If not ligated, the appendicular artery may cause bleeding complications.

questions.text: Which of the below is the most preferred investigation for parathyroid adenoma localisation? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sestamibi SPECT

 

This is the preferred diagnostic tool for identifying parathyroid adenomas. The technique involves the use of a radioactive tracer, typically Technetium-99m sestamibi, which is absorbed by hyperactive parathyroid tissue more than normal tissue. SPECT provides three-dimensional imaging, improving the localization of hyperactive parathyroid glands.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT (Computed Tomography): CT scans are not typically the first line of imaging due to the high levels of radiation exposure and the potential need for contrast agents.

 

Option C. Technetium-99m Sestamibi (tech99-Sestamibi) scan: This is a nuclear imaging which uses a gamma camera for imaging.

 

Option D. USG (Ultrasound): Ultrasound is a non-invasive, widely available, and less expensive method to examine the neck for parathyroid adenomas. It is particularly useful in conjunction with Sestamibi scans, as it helps to evaluate the structure of the neck and localize adenomas. However, its effectiveness can be limited by the operator's experience and the patient's anatomy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While all these methods can assist in the diagnosis and localization of parathyroid adenomas, Sestamibi SPECT is generally considered the most effective standalone imaging modality due to its high specificity for active parathyroid tissue and its ability to provide detailed spatial resolution. It is particularly valuable in surgical planning to ensure precise removal of the adenoma.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with an ulcerative lesion noted near the nose/medical canthus. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Basal cell carcinoma 

 

  • The patient's presentation with an ulcerative lesion near the nose/medial canthus with rolled out edges is a basal cell carcinoma. 

 

This is the most common type of skin cancer, often appearing in sun-exposed areas such as the face. BCC frequently presents as a pearly bump with telangiectatic vessels or as a flat, flesh-colored or brown scar-like lesion. Ulceration is common in neglected or advanced BCC, particularly near critical areas like the nose and eyes, where it can cause significant local destruction. Given its common presentation and the description provided, BCC is a very likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lentigo Maligna Melanoma: This is a type of melanoma that typically occurs on sun-exposed areas of the skin, particularly the face and the arms, in older adults. It begins as a patch that darkens, enlarges, and sometimes becomes nodular, indicating progression to melanoma. It's less common for lentigo maligna to present initially as an ulcerative lesion, making this a less likely diagnosis.

 

Option C. Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC): SCC is a type of skin cancer that can also appear on sun-exposed skin and may develop from a pre-existing actinic keratosis. It can be more aggressive than BCC and typically presents as a thick, rough, scaly patch that can bleed if bumped. It can ulcerate but often has a more rapid growth compared to BCC.

 

Option D. Nevus: A nevus is a common skin growth (mole), which can be present from birth or appear during childhood or young adulthood. While most nevi are benign, changes in their appearance, such as ulceration, require evaluation to rule out malignant transformation, such as into melanoma.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Given the description of an ulcerative lesion near critical areas like the nose and medial canthus, Basal Cell Carcinoma is the most probable diagnosis due to its frequent occurrence in these regions and its tendency to ulcerate. Treatment typically involves surgical excision, and in some cases, topical or systemic therapy may be considered.

questions.text: A patient following head injury with altered consciousness, vomiting, and GCS of 10/15 undergoes CT scan as shown. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decompression

 

The patient presents with signs of an acute epidural hematoma (EDH), as evidenced by the biconvex (lens-shaped) hyperdense lesion on the CT scan, along with a deteriorating Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 10/15. An epidural hematoma is a neurosurgical emergency, especially when accompanied by neuro deterioration, as in this case. The immediate next step is decompression, which involves relieving the pressure on the brain by surgically removing the hematoma. This procedure can be done through a burr hole or craniotomy and is crucial to prevent further brain injury or death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV Mannitol: Although IV mannitol is used to reduce intracranial pressure, it is not the definitive treatment for an acute EDH with neuro deterioration. Mannitol may be used temporarily to manage intracranial pressure, but it does not address the underlying cause of the pressure, which is the hematoma.

 

Option B. Wait and watch: This approach is inappropriate in this scenario due to the immediate threat posed by the hematoma. Delaying treatment could lead to irreversible brain damage or death.

 

Option D. Anticoagulation: Administering anticoagulation would exacerbate the bleeding and worsen the patient’s condition. It is contraindicated in the setting of an active intracranial hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epidural hematoma with neuro deterioration is a neurosurgical emergency that requires immediate decompression to prevent further brain injury and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following option is a common size of a Foley catheter used in female patients and patients who have had urethral surgery or who have strictures? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 14 Fr

 

14 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 14 Fr are commonly used in adult female patients. They are also used in patients who have had urethral surgery or who have strictures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 6 Fr: 6 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 6 Fr are commonly used in pediatric patients or in adults with narrow urethras. They are also used in urodynamic studies to measure bladder pressures.

 

Option C. 16 Fr: 16 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 16 Fr are commonly used in adult male patients. They are also used in patients who have had urethral surgery or who have strictures.

 

Option D. 22 Fr: 22 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 22 Fr are commonly used in patients for suprapubic cystostomy. They are also used in patients who have undergone prostate surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FOLEY’S CATHETER

 

The size in French (12F, 14F, 16F etc.) represents the outer diameter. 1 F = 1/3rd mm.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient with obstructive jaundice has a distended gall bladder and a dilated common bile duct and intrahepatic biliary radicles on ultrasound. Which of the following will be most useful to localize the cause? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)

 

Given scenario of an elderly male with obstructive jaundice and distended gall bladder, is suggestive of periampullary tumour. The best investigation would be a CECT abdomen (not provided in the option) or MRCP.

 

Correct. MRCP is a non-invasive imaging technique that visualizes the biliary and pancreatic ducts. It provides detailed images without the need for ionizing radiation or invasive procedures. Given the patient's age and presentation, MRCP is an ideal choice to visualize obstructions or abnormalities in the bile duct system without posing additional risks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endoscopic ultrasound: This is a useful modality for visualizing the biliary tree, pancreas, and surrounding structures. It can be particularly helpful in assessing small lesions or stones that might be missed by other imaging modalities. It would be utilised if MRCP/CECT did not yield adequate diagnosis, or for staging of periampullary tumors.

 

Option C. Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography: This is an invasive procedure where contrast is injected directly into the biliary system through the liver, and then X-rays are taken. It can be diagnostic as well as therapeutic (e.g., for bile duct drainage). However, it's more invasive than MRCP and might not be the first choice for solely diagnostic purposes in a 72-year-old patient.

 

Option D. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP): ERCP is both diagnostic and therapeutic. It involves inserting an endoscope through the mouth to the duodenum and injecting contrast into the bile and pancreatic ducts. While ERCP can visualize and treat obstructions, it's invasive and carries risks like pancreatitis, especially if used primarily for diagnostic purposes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obstructive jaundice is a condition in which there is a blockage of the flow of bile out of the liver. This results in redirection of excess bile and its by-products into the blood, and bile excretion from the body is incomplete

 

Symptoms of obstructive jaundice include yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes; paler stools and darker urine; and intense itching.

 

The most common cause of obstructive jaundice is the presence of CBD stones (choledocholithiasis). Other causes of obstructive jaundice are tumors, trauma, cysts, and inflammation in the bile ducts.

questions.text: Identify the following image: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ranula

 

The given clinical scenario and the image showing a cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth points to a diagnosis of a Ranula.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemangioma: A benign tumor made up of blood vessels, often appearing as a birthmark or red growth.

 

Option B. Cystic hygroma: A fluid-filled sac that results from a blockage in the lymphatic system, often present at birth. It presents as a posterior neck swelling.

 

Option C. Branchial cyst: A congenital epithelial cyst that arises from remnants of the branchial arches, usually presenting as a neck lump.

questions.text: Identify the incision made and marked is the image: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gibson 

 

  • The Gibson incision is correct in this scenario, assuming the surgical mark and procedure are aimed at accessing structures in the lower quadrant of the abdomen or the pelvis. This incision provides the necessary exposure while minimizing damage to the muscular and nerve structures

 

This is a type of oblique incision made along the line of the inguinal ligament. It is primarily used for procedures involving the lower ureter, pelvic kidney, or bladder surgery. It provides excellent exposure to the lower abdomen and pelvic areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Robson Incision: This is also known as the "classic gridiron" incision. It's a muscle-splitting incision used primarily for accessing the appendix during an appendectomy. It runs obliquely in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen.

 

Option B. Battle Incision: Less commonly referenced, this incision isn't widely recognized in standard surgical texts under this name. It may refer to a specialized or less commonly used approach.

 

Option D. Kocher Incision: This incision is typically used for biliary surgery. It is a subcostal incision made parallel to the costal margin, usually on the right side, to provide access to the gallbladder and biliary tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gibson Incision is a type of oblique incision made along the line of the inguinal ligament. It is primarily used for procedures involving the lower ureter, pelvic kidney, or bladder surgery

questions.text:
A 65-year-old patient is admitted to the hospital with septic shock. The physician decides to administer vasopressors to manage the patient's condition. The patient also requires multiple infusions that are not compatible with peripheral intravenous access. A central venous catheter is inserted into the patient's internal jugular vein. Which of the following statements are true regarding central and peripheral venous access and their associated complications? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Phlebitis is the most common complication associated with peripheral venous access.
  2. Flushing with isotonic saline and heparin can maintain patency in both central and peripheral venous catheters.
  3. If an arteriovenous fistula is present in a limb, peripheral venous access should be avoided in that same limb.
  4. Vasopressors used for septic shock are typically administered via a central venous catheter to avoid limb ischemia.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Statement 1 is true as phlebitis is the most common complication associated with peripheral venous access.

 

Statement 2 is also true as flushing with isotonic saline and heparin is used to maintain patency in both central and peripheral venous catheters.

 

Statement 3 is true as the presence of an arteriovenous fistula in a limb is a relative contraindication for peripheral venous access in that same limb.

 

Statement 4 is also true as vasopressors used for septic shock are typically administered via a central venous catheter to avoid limb ischemia.

 

In this clinical case, the patient's septic shock required vasopressors, and multiple infusions that are not compatible with peripheral intravenous access, leading to the insertion of a central venous catheter into the internal jugular vein. To prevent or avoid the formation of thrombus in venous catheters, the solutions used include 0.9% sodium chloride, heparin, vitamin C, and sodium citrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Septic shock is a life-threatening medical condition that occurs as a result of a severe infection leading to a systemic inflammatory response. It is characterized by a combination of infection, low blood pressure (hypotension), and organ dysfunction. Here are some key points about septic shock:

 

  1. Infection: Septic shock typically begins with an infection, often caused by bacteria, but it can also result from fungal or viral infections. Common sources of infection include lung infections (pneumonia), urinary tract infections, abdominal infections, and skin infections.
  2. Systemic Inflammatory Response: In response to the infection, the body's immune system initiates a widespread inflammatory response. This response can become dysregulated, leading to an exaggerated release of inflammatory molecules (cytokines) into the bloodstream.
  3. Hypotension: One of the hallmark features of septic shock is low blood pressure (hypotension). The inflammation and vasodilation caused by the infection can lead to a drop in blood pressure, which can result in inadequate blood flow to vital organs.
  4. Organ Dysfunction: As blood pressure drops and organs receive less oxygen and nutrients, multiple organ systems can begin to fail. This can lead to dysfunction in the heart, lungs, kidneys, liver, and other organs. Organ dysfunction is a critical component of septic shock and contributes to its high mortality rate.
  5. Symptoms: Symptoms of septic shock can include fever or hypothermia (low body temperature), rapid heart rate, rapid breathing, confusion, altered mental status, and signs of organ dysfunction such as respiratory distress, kidney failure, or liver dysfunction.
  6. Treatment: The treatment of septic shock is a medical emergency and involves aggressive interventions. It typically includes antibiotics to treat the underlying infection, intravenous fluids to maintain blood pressure, vasopressor medications to constrict blood vessels and raise blood pressure, and supportive care in an intensive care unit (ICU).

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios is a liver transplant possible in the case of secondary tumours? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ca testis

 

  • Liver transplantation for metastatic cancer is generally considered with extreme caution due to the high risk of recurrence and the limited availability of organs. However, certain exceptions exist based on the specific type of cancer and its overall prognosis and responsiveness to other treatments. Here's an analysis of the scenarios mentioned:

 

In rare cases, liver transplantation might be considered for metastatic testicular cancer if it is isolated to the liver and the primary cancer is under control. Testicular cancer tends to have a better overall prognosis compared to many other cancers due to its high responsiveness to chemotherapy. If the metastasis is limited and other treatments have been effective, liver transplantation could be a potential option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Melanoma: Liver transplantation is not typically recommended for metastatic melanoma due to the aggressive nature of the disease and the likelihood of widespread metastasis. Melanoma is known to respond poorly to immunosuppression, which is a requisite part of post-transplant care.

 

Option B. Breast Cancer (Ca breast): Like melanoma, metastatic breast cancer is generally not considered suitable for liver transplantation. Breast cancer can metastasize to multiple organs, and the post-transplant immunosuppression regime can exacerbate the spread and recurrence of the cancer.

 

Option D. Active Renal Cell Carcinoma (Active RCC): RCC is typically resistant to both chemotherapy and radiation, and like melanoma and breast cancer, is generally not considered suitable for liver transplantation due to poor outcomes associated with the disease's aggressive nature and potential for widespread metastatic sites.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liver transplantation for metastatic cancer is rare and generally only considered under specific conditions. These conditions typically include the isolation of metastasis to the liver, good control of the primary cancer, and a lack of other effective treatment options. Each type of cancer must be evaluated on its own characteristics, including its responsiveness to treatment and overall prognosis.

questions.text: A patient reports pain in the right upper abdomen. An ultrasound-guided FNAC of liver cysts reveals the presence of a parasitic organism. Which of the following is most likely to be the causative organism? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echinococcus granulosus

 

Echinococcus granulosus is the causative organism for hydatid cyst of the liver. The diagnosis is based on:

 

  • Location - Liver is the most common site for hydatid cysts
  • Imaging - Characteristic appearance on ultrasound
  • FNAC findings - Demonstrates scolices and hooklets of Echinococcus
  • Life cycle involves: 
    • Definitive host: Dog
    • Intermediate host: Sheep
    • Accidental host: Humans (dead end)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Taenia saginata : Incorrect. Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm) does not typically cause liver cysts. It mainly affects the intestine.

 

Option C. Taenia solium: Incorrect. Taenia solium (pork tapeworm) is associated with neurocysticercosis affecting the brain and muscles, not liver cysts.

 

Option D. H. nana: Incorrect. Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) is an intestinal parasite and does not cause liver cysts.

 

Educational Objective: 


Echinococcus granulosus is the causative organism for hydatid cysts of the liver, which is the most common site of hydatid disease.

choices.text: Gall bladder thickness >3 mm on USG
Preferential visualization of gall bladder in HIDA scan

questions.text: 50-year-old obese female presents to the emergency department with severe right upper quadrant pain, fever, and nausea. The physician suspects acute cholecystitis and orders imaging studies to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following statements is not true about acute cholecystitis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Preferential visualization of gall bladder in HIDA scan.

 

This statement is not true. In a Hepatobiliary Iminodiacetic Acid (HIDA) scan, the gallbladder is not preferentially visualized in acute cholecystitis. Instead, one of the hallmark findings in acute cholecystitis on a HIDA scan is non-visualization of the gallbladder due to inflammation and obstruction of the cystic duct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gall bladder thickness >3 mm on USG: This statement is true and is a common finding in acute cholecystitis. On ultrasound (USG), a thickened gallbladder wall, typically greater than 3 mm, is indicative of inflammation and is a characteristic feature of acute cholecystitis.

 

Option B. Murphy's sign positive: This statement is true. Murphy's sign is a clinical maneuver used to assess for acute cholecystitis. It involves palpation of the right upper quadrant during inspiration, and if the patient experiences pain or stops breathing due to pain during this maneuver, it is considered a positive Murphy's sign, suggesting inflammation of the gallbladder.

 

Option C. Leukocytosis: This statement is true. Acute cholecystitis is associated with an inflammatory response, leading to an elevation in white blood cell count, which is known as leukocytosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute cholecystitis is a common condition characterized by inflammation of the gallbladder, typically due to the presence of gallstones obstructing the cystic duct. Clinical features of acute cholecystitis include right upper quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis. A positive Murphy's sign is right upper quadrant tenderness on palpation. On ultrasound imaging, gall bladder thickness >3 mm is a common finding in acute cholecystitis. The HIDA scan is a diagnostic tool for acute cholecystitis, showing non-visualization of the gall bladder 3 hours after radioisotope administration. Preferential visualization of the gall bladder on a HIDA scan is not a feature of acute cholecystitis. It is important to diagnose and treat acute cholecystitis promptly to prevent complications such as gallbladder perforation or gangrene.

questions.text: In a patient with renal stones, the following crystals suggest what etiology? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triple phosphate

 

The image provided in the question shows crystals that are described as "coffin-lid" shaped. These crystals are characteristic of triple phosphate stones, also known as struvite stones. Struvite stones are commonly associated with urinary tract infections caused by urease-producing bacteria, which raise the urine pH and promote the formation of these crystals.

 

  • Triple Phosphate Crystals (Struvite): These crystals have a distinctive coffin-lid shape, which is clearly depicted in the image. They are typically seen in alkaline urine and are associated with infections, especially those caused by urease-producing organisms like Proteus, Klebsiella, or Pseudomonas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uric Acid: Uric acid crystals are usually rhomboid or rosette-shaped. They form in acidic urine and are not associated with the coffin-lid appearance shown in the image.

 

Option C. Calcium Oxalate Monohydrate: These crystals have a dumbbell or ovoid shape, not resembling the coffin-lid appearance in the image.

 

Option D. Calcium Oxalate Dihydrate: These crystals are typically envelope-shaped, resembling a square with a diagonal cross. While they might be confused with the coffin-lid shape, they are distinctively different.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coffin-lid shaped crystals in a urine analysis are indicative of triple phosphate stones, commonly associated with urinary tract infections and alkaline urine.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents with dysphagia, weight loss, and halitosis. What is the most probable diagnosis based on the image provided? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Achalasia

 

Achalasia is a condition characterized by the inability of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax properly, leading to difficulty in swallowing (dysphagia), weight loss, and regurgitation. The typical radiological finding in achalasia is a smooth narrowing and gradual tapering at the lower esophagus, often described as a "bird's beak" appearance. The presence of dysphagia, weight loss, and halitosis (bad breath) in a young patient, along with the image showing smooth narrowing, points strongly towards achalasia. The halitosis, though mentioned, is often not a significant feature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ca esophagus: This condition would typically present with progressive dysphagia rather than the intermittent dysphagia seen in achalasia. Halitosis is not commonly associated with esophageal cancer, and the radiological appearance would differ, showing irregular narrowing rather than the smooth tapering seen in achalasia.

 

Option C. Corrosive stricture: This would likely present with a history of corrosive ingestion and would show irregular, scarred, and narrowed areas of the esophagus, not the smooth tapering characteristic of achalasia.

 

Option D. Zenker's diverticulum: This condition can present with dysphagia and halitosis due to the trapping of food in the diverticulum, but the radiological appearance is quite distinct, typically showing a pouch at the pharyngoesophageal junction. The image provided does not suggest this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic triad of dysphagia, weight loss, and regurgitation in a young patient, along with imaging showing smooth narrowing and gradual tapering, is highly suggestive of achalasia.

choices.text: Radical/ wide excision of GB fossa

questions.text: A patent underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The histopathology specimen reveals carcinoma with invasion into the muscularis propria. What is the next best step? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Radical/ wide excision of GB fossa

 

  • In the scenario of a patient with a gallbladder carcinoma discovered incidentally following a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, where the carcinoma has invaded the muscularis propria, the next step in management should focus on ensuring complete removal of any residual malignant tissue and preventing local recurrence.
  • Radical or wide excision of the gallbladder fossa is the recommended course of action. This involves excising the gallbladder bed to the level of the liver parenchyma and possibly lymph node dissection to ensure any potential spread or residual disease is addressed. This approach is supported by the need to achieve negative margins, as gallbladder cancer can be aggressive and has a tendency to infiltrate the liver and surrounding structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiotherapy and B. Chemotherapy might be considered as adjunct therapies depending on the stage of the cancer, pathological findings from the re-excision, and the patient's overall health status. However, they are not the primary step immediately following the discovery of invasive gallbladder cancer in a post-cholecystectomy specimen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radical/wide excision of the GB fossa is indeed the appropriate next step to prevent local recurrence and potentially improve survival outcomes. This decision is based on the depth of tumor invasion and the general aggressiveness of gallbladder cancers.

questions.text: Identify the type of drain: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closed

 

The image displays a Romovac drain placed after mastectomy, which is a closed-type drain. Drains are utilized at surgical sites to collect air or fluid buildup, promoting wound healing by preventing cavity formation. Drains can be prophylactic in elective surgeries and therapeutic in emergency surgeries, with open, semi-open, and closed types.

 

They carry out their actions through suction

 

  • Eg. Romovac drain, Jackson Pratt drain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open: They are based on the principle of gravity or capillary effect

 

  • Eg. Corrugated drain, Foley’s catheter etc.\

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Romovac drain is a closed negative suction drain placed in subcutaneous tissue and indicated in modified radical mastectomy, subcutaneous swelling excision, and amputations. Other specialized drains include chest drains for air removal from the pleural cavity and T-tubes for bile drainage after surgical exploration of the bile duct.

questions.text: A patient who is suffering from a pressure sore on examination is found to have partially broken skin with a shallow ulcer. What is the grade of the sore? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2

 

Pressure sore grading:

 

  • Grade 1: Non-blanching erythema with intact skin
  • Grade 2: Partial thickness skin loss involving epidermis/dermis, shallow ulcer
  • Grade 3: Full thickness skin loss with visible subcutaneous fat
  • Grade 4: Full thickness tissue loss with exposed bone/muscle/tendon In this case,  partial skin loss with shallow ulcer indicates Grade 2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grade 1:

 

  • Only shows non-blanching erythema
  • Skin remains intact
  • No ulceration present

 

Option C. Grade 3:

 

  • Shows full-thickness skin loss
  • Subcutaneous fat visible
  • Deeper than described in question

 

Option D. Grade 4:

 

  • Represents full thickness tissue loss
  • Exposes deeper structures (bone/muscle/tendon)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Grade 2 pressure sore is characterized by partial thickness skin loss with shallow ulceration, without exposure of deeper tissues.

 

Stages:

 

  1. Non blanching erythema with intact skin
  2. Partial thickness skin loss (some skin intact)
  3. Full thickness loss (subcut, Fat seen)
  4. Subcut, Loss (deep fascia/muscles/bones tendons seen)

 

 

Management:

 

  • Avoid continuous supine position → frequent change in position 
  • Use of air mattress/water bed
  • Cover the pressure sore: fascia lata flap/ negative pressure wound therapy (VAC dressing)

choices.text: Tumor size < 4cm, with N1 axillary metastasis
Tumor size exceeding the size of the breast

questions.text: Which of the options below is an acceptable condition for breast conservative surgery? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tumor size <4cm, with N1 axillary metastasis

 

Options B, C, and D are contraindications for breast conservative surgery, whereas option A is an acceptable condition for breast conservative surgery.

 

Breast-conserving surgery, also known as lumpectomy or partial mastectomy, is a suitable option when the primary tumor in the breast is relatively small (typically less than 4 cm). Presence of N1 disease (ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph node metastasis) is not a contra-indicated. However, since LN are already involved, a sentinel lymph biopsy is not needed, and up front axillary lymphadenectomy is done.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tumor size exceeding the size of the breast: Breast-conserving surgery aims to remove the tumor while preserving as much of the breast tissue as possible. If the tumor size exceeds the size of the breast, it may not be feasible to perform breast-conserving surgery, as there would be insufficient healthy breast tissue remaining.

 

Option C. Previous chest irradiation: Previous chest irradiation, especially at high doses, can affect the breast tissue's tolerance to additional radiation. It may limit the use of breast-conserving surgery due to concerns about radiation toxicity.

 

Option D. Presence of multiple tumors: Breast-conserving surgery is typically performed for a single primary tumor in the breast. If there are multiple tumors in different areas of the breast, it may not be suitable for breast-conserving surgery, as it may be challenging to achieve clear margins and preserve breast tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Breast conservative surgery involves the removal of the primary breast cancer with adequate normal breast tissue, followed by adjuvant radiotherapy and assessment of regional lymph nodes through a separate axillary incision.

 

Absolute contraindications for breast conservative surgery include pregnancy, persistently positive margins, multicentric lumps, diffuse microcalcification, extensive ductal carcinoma in situ, and inflammatory breast cancer.

 

Relative contraindications include active systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, a large lump-to-breast ratio (>5 cm size lump), known or suspected genetic predisposition to breast cancer (i.e., BRCA1, BRCA2), multifocal disease, and prior radiation therapy to the chest wall or breast.

questions.text: Which of the following suture materials is commonly used in neurosurgery and microsurgery? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nylon

 

Nylon is a non-absorbable suture material and is commonly used in neurosurgery, microsurgery, and ophthalmic surgery due to its low tissue reaction and high tensile strength.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polyglactin: Polyglactin (Vicryl) is an absorbable braided suture material and is commonly used in general surgical practices for gut anastomoses, vascular ligatures, subcuticular wound closures, and ophthalmic surgery.

 

Option C. Polypropylene 1-0 & Option D. Polypropylene 2-0: Polypropylene is a non-absorbable suture material and is used in plastic surgery, cardiovascular surgery, hernia repair. Polypropylene 1-0 and 2-0 refer to the size or diameter of the suture, with 1-0 being larger than 2-0. These sutures are too thick to be used in microsurgery.

 

Therefore, options B, C, and D are incorrect as they do not match the given description.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of these is not a risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hepatitis B infection

 

Cholangiocarcinoma, a type of cancer that forms in the bile ducts, has several well-established risk factors. These include chronic inflammatory conditions like primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), parasitic infections such as Opisthorchis viverrini, and congenital conditions like Caroli's disease. However, while Hepatitis C is recognized as a risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma, Hepatitis B is not commonly associated with this type of cancer. The confusion often arises because Hepatitis B is a major risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma, another type of liver cancer, but not specifically for cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Caroli's disease: Caroli's disease is a congenital disorder characterized by the dilation of the bile ducts and is associated with an increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC): PSC is a chronic liver disease that causes inflammation and scarring of the bile ducts. It is a well-known risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Option D. Opisthorchis V. (Opisthorchis viverrini): Opisthorchis viverrini, a liver fluke, is a parasitic infection known to increase the risk of cholangiocarcinoma, especially in endemic regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B infection is not a recognized risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma. Instead, focus on chronic inflammatory conditions, parasitic infections, and certain congenital disorders as key risk factors for this type of cancer.

questions.text:
Which of these are included in extra-esophageal symptoms of GERD? (multiple correct combinations) (INICET MAY 2024)

 

a. Asthma
b. Laryngitis
c. Excessive phlegm
d. Pulmonary fibrosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is typically associated with symptoms such as heartburn, epigastric pain, and acid reflux. However, GERD can also present with a variety of extra-esophageal symptoms, which are manifestations outside the esophagus. These symptoms arise due to the aspiration of gastric contents or the stimulation of vagal reflexes.

 

  • Asthma: Nocturnal asthma can be triggered or exacerbated by GERD due to the reflux of stomach acid that can reach the airways, leading to bronchoconstriction.
  • Laryngitis: Laryngitis can occur when acid reflux irritates the laryngeal mucosa, leading to hoarseness or loss of voice.
  • Excessive phlegm: GERD can lead to chronic throat clearing and excessive phlegm production as the body attempts to clear the irritating reflux material from the throat.
  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Although less common, repeated aspiration of gastric contents can cause chronic inflammation in the lungs, leading to pulmonary fibrosis over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Since the  includes all options, there are no incorrect choices to explain in this instance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GERD can manifest not only with typical esophageal symptoms like heartburn but also with extra-esophageal symptoms such as asthma, laryngitis, excessive phlegm, and even pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.text: What is the angle between the laparoscopic working port and telescope called? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Azimuth angle

 

In laparoscopic surgery:

 

  • Azimuth angle: Angle between working port and telescope (15-30 degrees)
  • Essential for ergonomic comfort during surgery
  • Prevents instrument clash with camera
  • Not possible to generate in single incision laparoscopic surgery
  • Inadequate angle leads to difficulty in surgery

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Elevation angle:

 

  • This is the angle between instrument and abdominal wall
  • Refers to vertical orientation of instruments
  • Not related to telescope-port relationship

 

Option C. Working angle:

 

  • Not a standard term in laparoscopic ergonomics
  • No specific angle is defined by this term

 

Option D. Manipulation angle:

 

  • This is the angle between two working ports
  • Refers to the angle between the surgeon's right and left-hand instruments
  • Different from telescope-port relationship

 

Educational Objective:

 

The angle between the laparoscopic working port and telescope is called the Azimuth angle, which should ideally be 15-30 degrees for optimal ergonomics.

choices.text: Cyst is opened and drainage done

questions.text: Incorrect statement about choledocal cyst is: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cyst is opened and drainage done 

 

The preferred treatment for choledochal cysts is not merely opening and draining them, but rather complete surgical removal of the cyst (cyst excision) and reconstruction of the biliary drainage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma: The risk of cholangiocarcinoma in patients with choledochal cysts can be significantly higher than in the general population. Regular monitoring and prophylactic surgical intervention are often recommended to manage this risk.

 

Option C. Todani classification used for grading: The Todani classification is indeed used to categorize choledochal cysts based on their anatomical location and type. This classification helps guide the treatment approach and prognostic assessment, making it fundamental in the management of choledochal cysts.

 

Option D. Associated with abnormal biliopancreatic junction: Choledochal cysts are often associated with an abnormal junction of the pancreatic and biliary ducts. This anomaly can lead to pancreatic juices refluxing into the bile duct, increasing the risk of inflammation and subsequent complications like cyst formation and malignancy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While the management of choledochal cysts involves a comprehensive approach considering the risk of malignancy, the appropriate surgical intervention usually entails the complete removal of the cyst and careful reconstruction of the biliary system, not just simple drainage.

questions.text: Open cardiac massage is what kind of wound? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Contaminated

 

  • In surgical practice, wounds are categorized based on their potential contamination during the procedure, which plays a crucial role in determining the risk of infection and guiding the prophylactic antibiotic therapy. Here’s an explanation of each category in the context of an open cardiac massage:

 

This category includes open, fresh, accidental wounds and operations with major breaks in sterile technique or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract. Contaminated wounds also include incisions in which acute, non-purulent inflammation is encountered. Open cardiac massage often involves emergency entry into the chest, which may not always comply with optimal sterile conditions, especially in traumatic or urgent contexts, thus falling into this category.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clean: These are wounds where no inflammation is encountered, and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or uninfected urinary tracts are not entered. Clean wounds are primarily closed and do not involve placement of a drain. The risk of infection is typically the lowest in clean wounds.

 

Option C. Dirty: These wounds involve the presence of pus or perforated viscera. This kind of wound shows evidence of a bacterial infection or major contamination prior to surgery. Dirty wounds are at high risk of developing postoperative infections.

 

Option D. Clean Contaminated: These wounds involve operations on the alimentary, respiratory, genital, or urinary tracts under controlled conditions without unusual contamination. Typically, these procedures involve some minor breaks in sterile technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Open cardiac massage is categorized as a Contaminated wound due to the nature of emergency procedures that may involve rapid and less controlled entry into the chest cavity, leading to a higher risk of infection compared to clean surgeries. This classification underscores the importance of using appropriate antibiotic prophylaxis and stringent postoperative care to manage and minimize the risk of infection

questions.text: During the separation of the spleen from the stomach while performing splenectomy, bleeding is likely to occur from which source? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Short gastric artery


During splenectomy, when separating the spleen from the stomach near the fundus, the short gastric vessels are most likely to bleed. These vessels are branches of the splenic artery that supply the fundus of the stomach. The short gastric vessels run in the gastrosplenic ligament connecting the fundus of the stomach to the splenic hilum. These vessels must be divided during splenectomy and can be a source of bleeding during or after the procedure.

 

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Left gastroepiploic artery: Incorrect. Left gastroepiploic artery runs along the greater curvature of the stomach and is not typically encountered during the fundal dissection of splenectomy.

 

Option C. Right gastroepiploic artery: Incorrect. Right gastroepiploic artery is on the right side of the greater curvature and is not involved in splenic dissection.

 

Option D. Splenic artery: Incorrect. The main splenic artery runs at a lower level on the superior border of the pancreas and is not encountered during the fundal dissection. It would only be encountered during posterior dissection or pancreatic surgery.

 

Educational Objective:


Short gastric vessels running in the gastrosplenic ligament between the splenic hilum and gastric fundus are the most likely source of bleeding during splenic dissection from stomach during splenectomy.

questions.text: A female presented with an ulcerated breast lump. Nipple retraction was seen, with some warmth and redness. On biopsy, it was diagnosed as invasive ductal carcinoma. According to AJCC 8th Ed., which of these correctly represents the stage? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T4b

 

In the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) 8th edition staging system, the classification of breast cancer stages is detailed based on tumor size, lymph node involvement, and the presence of metastasis.

 

The presentation of an ulcerated breast lump, nipple retraction, warmth, and redness suggests skin involvement, which is characteristic of a T4 classification. Specifically, the presence of ulceration and skin involvement corresponds to T4b. T4b is used when there is skin involvement in the form of ulceration, satellite skin nodules, or peau d’orange (skin changes resembling the texture of an orange).
