While there is the possibility of inflammatory breast cancer due to the warmth and redness, the key feature here is ulceration, which is more indicative of T4b. Inflammatory breast cancer would correspond to a T4d classification, characterized by more extensive skin changes like diffuse erythema and edema (peau d'orange) involving more than one-third of the breast, often with underlying invasive ductal carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage IV with N1-N2 involvement: This is incorrect as there is no evidence of distant metastasis (M1), which is required for a Stage IV classification. The presence of regional lymph node involvement (N1-N2) alone does not justify a Stage IV classification.

 

Option C. Stage IIIB: This could be considered if the case were inflammatory breast cancer, but based on the ulceration and other features described, T4b is more appropriate unless additional evidence of inflammatory changes was present.

 

Option D. It cannot be M1: This statement is partially correct as the case does not mention any distant metastasis (M1), but it doesn’t address the primary tumor stage, which is the focus of the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulceration of a breast lump with skin involvement typically corresponds to T4b in the AJCC 8th edition staging system for breast cancer. It is essential to differentiate between T4b and T4d (inflammatory breast cancer) based on the clinical presentation and pathological findings.

choices.text: Incontinence when patient lies down and coughs

questions.text: A 37-year-old male comes with lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS). Which of the following is not a typical presenting LUTS? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Incontinence during intercourse

 

While urinary incontinence during intercourse can occur, it is not considered a typical lower urinary tract symptom (LUTS). LUTS typically encompasses symptoms related to storage and voiding of urine. Incontinence during intercourse might be related to other causes, including psychological factors, or specific conditions impacting the pelvic floor, but it's not a routine symptom when discussing LUTS.

 

Incontinence during sexual activity is not considered a lower urinary tract symptom (LUTS).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sudden urge to urinate: This symptom is known as urgency and is a common lower urinary tract symptom. It is the sudden and strong desire to urinate, which can be difficult to delay.

 

Option B. Incontinence while asleep: This is referred to as nocturnal enuresis or bedwetting. It is a type of urinary incontinence where the patient involuntarily releases urine during sleep. This can be a symptom associated with a variety of conditions, including bladder issues, sleep disorders, or even psychological factors.

 

Option C. Incontinence when a patient lies down and coughs: This is known as stress incontinence. It occurs when physical movement or activity, such as coughing, sneezing, running, or heavy lifting, puts pressure (stress) on the bladder, causing unintentional urine leakage. It's often due to weakened pelvic floor muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LUTS can be divided into three categories: storage, voiding, and post-micturitional.

 

Storage LUTS involves the failure of the bladder to act as a urine reservoir, leading to symptoms such as increased frequency of voiding, nocturia, urgency, and urge incontinence.

 

Voiding LUTS is commonly seen in bladder outlet obstruction and includes symptoms such as hesitancy, reduced stream, and straining.

 

Post-micturitional LUTS, also caused by bladder outlet obstruction, includes symptoms such as incomplete emptying and post-micturition dribble. Other symptoms of LUTS include stress incontinence, nocturnal enuresis, and strangury.

questions.text: Which is a not a risk factor for Carcinoma of Gall bladder? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Polyp <10 mm

 

Gallbladder polyps are growths that emerge from the lining of the gallbladder. Those that are smaller than 10 mm are generally considered less likely to be cancerous. The risk of cancer increases with the size of the polyp, especially if it is larger than 10 mm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Porcelain gallbladder: This condition is characterized by calcification of the gallbladder wall. It has been associated with an increased risk of gallbladder cancer.

 

Option B. Primary sclerosing cholangitis: This is a chronic biliary disease marked by inflammation and fibrosis of the bile ducts. People with primary sclerosing cholangitis have an elevated risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma and to a lesser extent, gallbladder cancer, especially if they develop gallbladder polyps.

 

Option D. Gallstone >3 cm: Large gallstones, especially those larger than 3 cm, have been linked with an increased risk of gallbladder cancer.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While porcelain gallbladders and large gallstones are established risk factors for gallbladder cancer, and primary sclerosing cholangitis has a known association with gallbladder malignancies, small gallbladder polyps (less than 10 mm) typically represent a lower risk for cancer.

choices.text: Lateral edge of pectoralis major muscle
Lateral border of latissimus dorsi muscle

questions.text: Which of the following is not a boundary of the triangle of safety for chest tube insertion in a patient with pneumothorax on chest X-ray? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mid-axillary line

 

The mid-axillary line is not a boundary of the triangle of safety. The triangle of safety is defined by specific anatomical landmarks and includes the lateral edge of the pectoralis major muscle, Latissimus dorse, and the fifth intercostal space inferiorly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral edge of pectoralis major muscle: This is the anterior boundary of the triangle of safety.

 

Option C. Base of axilla: This is a boundary of the triangle of safety. It is an important reference point for chest tube insertion to ensure it is performed safely and effectively.

 

Option D. Lateral border of latissimus dorsi muscle: This is a boundary of the triangle of safety. It helps guide the placement of the chest tube in a safe and appropriate location.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triangle of safety for chest tube insertion is a surgical landmark used to guide the safe insertion of chest tubes in patients with pneumothorax. The boundaries of the triangle are the lateral edge of the pectoralis major muscle, the lateral border of the latissimus dorsi muscle, and the 5th intercostal space (ICS) inferiorly, at the level of the nipple above and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle. The base of the triangle is formed by the anterior border of the latissimus dorsi muscle and the lateral edge of the serratus anterior muscle at the base of the axilla.

questions.text: A surgeon performs an appendicectomy with a grid iron incision. He later converts the incision to Rutherford Morrison incision. Which of the following are cut? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

When the initial Gridiron incision is converted to Rutherford Morrison incision, the external oblique, internal oblique, and transverse abdominis muscles are cut.

 

Gridiron incision is also known as McArthur’s incision. It is a muscle splitting incision used in open appendicectomy.

 

Rutherford Morrison incision is useful in cases where the appendix is para- or retrocaecal and fixed. The lower end of the incision is located over McBurney's point and extends obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary. It involves cutting through the skin, subcutaneous tissues, external oblique, underlying internal oblique, transversus abdominis, and peritoneum along the line of the incision.

 

The Lanz incision is a transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis, located 2 cm below the umbilicus and centered on the midclavicular-mid-inguinal line.

 

The Pfannenstiel incision is an infraumbilical transverse incision in the lower abdomen, often used for gynecological and obstetric procedures.

questions.text: In triage, immediately life-threatening injury is categorized as what color code? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red

 

In the triage system, which is used to prioritize patients based on the severity of their condition, an immediately life-threatening injury is classified under the Red color code. This indicates that the patient requires immediate medical attention to prevent death or severe complications. The Red category is the highest priority in triage, where intervention is needed within 0 to 6 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Green: This color code is used for ambulatory patients with non-life-threatening injuries. These patients are stable and can wait for treatment.

 

Option C. Yellow: The Yellow category is for urgent cases where intervention is required within 6 to 24 hours. While these patients need prompt attention, their condition is not as immediately critical as those in the Red category.

 

Option D. Black: The Black category is reserved for patients who are either deceased or moribund (those who are unlikely to survive). This represents the lowest priority in triage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a triage situation, an immediately life-threatening injury is classified under the Red color code, indicating the need for urgent medical intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is/are true about Crohn’s disease, in contrast to ulcerative colitis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) More risk of perianal fistulae

 

Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis are both types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), but they have distinct characteristics and should not be considered the same. Crohn's disease can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from the mouth to the anus, and is known for causing "skip lesions," meaning areas of diseased tissue interspersed with healthy tissue.

 

  • Perianal fistulae: Crohn’s disease is more associated with perianal complications, including fistulae, abscesses, and fissures, due to the deeper transmural inflammation that characterizes the disease. This is in contrast to ulcerative colitis, which primarily involves the mucosa and submucosa and starts from the rectum, rarely involving perianal areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lesions are continuous: This statement is incorrect for Crohn’s disease. Continuous lesions are characteristic of ulcerative colitis. In Crohn’s disease, the inflammation is patchy, with skip lesions being typical.

 

Option C. Malignancy is more common: Malignancy is more commonly associated with ulcerative colitis, particularly colorectal cancer, due to the long-standing inflammation typically confined to the colon. Crohn’s disease has a lower risk of malignancy.

 

Option D. Often presents with hematochezia: Hematochezia, or the passage of fresh blood in the stool, is more commonly associated with ulcerative colitis. Crohn’s disease typically presents with non-bloody diarrhea, although some cases might involve blood, it is not as frequent as in ulcerative colitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crohn’s disease is characterized by a higher risk of perianal fistulae and skip lesions, in contrast to ulcerative colitis, which presents with continuous lesions and a higher risk of colorectal malignancy.

choices.text: Cervical spine stabilization, intubation, IV cannulation, CECT
Intubation, cervical spine stabilization, IV cannulation, CECT
IV cannulation, cervical spine stabilization, intubation, CECT
IV cannulation, intubation, CECT, cervical spine stabilization

questions.text: In a patient who presents to the casualty with an RTA, what is the correct sequence of management? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cervical spine stabilization, intubation, IV cannulation, CECT

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cervical spine stabilization, intubation, IV cannulation, CECT is the correct sequence of management in a patient who presents to the casualty with an RTA.

 

The steps in Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) include the following: primary survey with simultaneous resuscitation, secondary survey, and definitive care.

 

The ABCDE of trauma care include Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate), Breathing and ventilation assessment, Circulation assessment, Disability assessment, and Exposure, with environmental control. During airway securing, cervical spine should be stabilised first (with a hard cervical collar) prior to attempting any manoeuvres like endotracheal intubation.

 

Adjuncts to the primary survey include blood tests, ECG, pulse oximetry, urinary and gastric catheters, and radiographs.

 

Specialized imaging like CECT should be considered after the secondary survey and only when the patient is stable after initial resuscitation.

questions.text: During total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer, which of the following steps will not lead to hoarseness of voice?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dissection of strap muscles

 

Hoarseness of voice after thyroidectomy is generally due to injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), which controls the vocal cords. The RLN is located near the thyroid gland, and careful surgical technique is necessary to avoid damaging it. The strap muscles, which are located anterior to the thyroid gland, are far from the path of the RLN, so dissecting these muscles will not result in hoarseness of voice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option  A. Dissection of Beahr’s triangle: The recurrent laryngeal nerve forms the anterior boundary of Beahr’s triangle, making it susceptible to injury during dissection, which can lead to hoarseness.

 

Option B. Dissection of Zuckerkandl tubercle: The Zuckerkandl tubercle is closely associated with the recurrent laryngeal nerve, so dissection in this area can risk nerve injury and subsequent hoarseness.

 

Option D. Ligation of Superior thyroid artery: This procedure is generally more likely to affect the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve rather than the recurrent laryngeal nerve, but in cases of anatomical variation, there is a small risk that the RLN could be affected, potentially leading to hoarseness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dissection of the strap muscles during thyroidectomy does not involve the recurrent laryngeal nerve, and therefore, will not cause hoarseness of voice.

questions.text: In a suspected case of cholangitis in a 47-year-old woman, what other component besides abdominal pain does not comprise Reynold's pentad? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hematemesis

 

Hematemesis (vomiting of blood) is not a component of Reynold's pentad. Reynold's pentad includes: jaundice, fever, abdominal pain, altered sensorium, and hypotension. Hematemesis can be a symptom of various other gastrointestinal issues but is not typically associated with cholangitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Cholangitis is an infection of the common bile duct caused by obstruction and increased pressure due to CBD stones.
  2. The classical triad of cholangitis (Charcot) is fever, right upper quadrant pain, and jaundice.
  3. If left untreated, cholangitis can progress to Reynold's pentad with hypotension and altered mental status due to sepsis.
  4. Abdominal ultrasound is used to diagnose biliary stones and bile duct dilatations in cholangitis.
  5. Treatment for cholangitis includes broad-spectrum antibiotics, rehydration, and biliary drainage using endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP).
  6. Biliary stones are the primary cause of cholangitis and can be removed by endoscopic sphincterotomy during ERCP.

choices.text: Lipase is more specific than amylase
Lipase requires 30 days to return to baseline
Lipase reflects the severity of pancreatitis
More than 75% of cases have hypercalcemia on admission

questions.text: Which of these is seen in acute pancreatitis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lipase is more specific than amylase

 

Lipase is indeed more specific than amylase in diagnosing acute pancreatitis. Amylase can be elevated in multiple other acute GI emergencies, while lipase elevation is more specific to pancreatic pathology. Lipase typically returns to baseline within 1-2 weeks (usually 12-15 days), not 30 days as stated in option B.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lipase requires 30 days to return to baseline: Incorrect. Lipase returns to baseline in 1-2 weeks, not 30 days

 

Option C. Lipase reflects the severity of pancreatitis: Incorrect. Neither lipase nor amylase levels reflect disease severity. Severity is assessed using other parameters like:

 

  • Atlanta classification
  • BISAP score
  • Older scoring systems like Ranson's criteria
  • CT severity index

 

Option D. More than 75% of cases have hypercalcemia on admission: Incorrect. Patients with acute pancreatitis typically develop hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia, due to saponification of calcium with free fatty acids. Hypercalcemia is very unusual in acute pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Lipase is more pancreas-specific than amylase and is the preferred diagnostic marker for acute pancreatitis.
  • Lipase does NOT indicate severity.
  • Most patients have hypocalcemia, NOT hypercalcemia.
  • Severity is assessed using clinical scores (BISAP, Ranson’s, APACHE-II) and imaging.

 

1st Investigation:

 

  1. Pancreatic enzymes are elevated in blood
    • Serum amylase (non specific) → rises early (4-6 hours of attack)
    • Serum lipase → rises 12-24 hours later (sensitive and specific, test of choice)
  2. Imaging → no need for diagnosis, only when unsure of dx, rule out etiology like gall stone Imaging modality of choice → CECT abdomen (done after 72 hours of symptoms)

questions.text: Which of these classifications of bile duct injury takes into account the location of injury, and thermal and vascular injury to bile ducts? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hannover 

 

  • When discussing bile duct injuries, several classification systems have been developed to categorize these injuries based on their nature, location, and the extent of damage. 

 

This system categorizes bile duct injuries based on the anatomical structure involved and the extent of the injury, including vascular injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bismuth Classification: Primarily focuses on the location of the bile duct injury in relation to the confluence of the right and left hepatic ducts. This classification is widely used to describe bile duct injuries post-cholecystectomy.

 

Option B. Strassberg Classification (also known as the Strassberg-Bismuth classification): This is an extension of the Bismuth classification, adding more detail and incorporating the critical view of safety concept. It includes acute injuries, but it is based on location alone. Associated vascular injuries are not included.

 

Option C. Stewart-Way Classification: This classification focuses on the phase of the operation in which the injury occurs and the type of injury, including thermal damage. It categorizes injuries into four types:

 

  1. Type I: Cystic duct leak or leakage from a small peripheral hepatic radicle close to the gallbladder fossa.
  2. Type II: Injury to the main bile duct that does not involve excision, typically a lateral injury.
  3. Type III: Complete transaction or excision of a segment of the main bile duct.
  4. Type IV: Injury involving damage to the hepatic duct confluence and bifurcation.

 

Stewart-Way classification does not account for associated vascular injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bismuth and Strassberg classifications are anatomically based classifications of bile duct injury.

questions.text: Most important prognostic factor for Ca Breast is: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Axillary lymph node status

 

Positive axillary lymph node involvement usually indicates a higher chance of recurrence and a poorer prognosis compared to no lymph node involvement. The number of affected lymph nodes also plays a crucial role in staging the cancer, which directly impacts treatment options and outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Size of the tumor: Generally, the larger the tumor, the worse the prognosis because a larger tumor size often correlates with a more advanced stage of cancer. Tumor size is considered when staging breast cancer, with larger tumors often requiring more aggressive treatment.

 

Option C. Distant metastasis: The presence of distant metastases (stage IV breast cancer) generally indicates a much poorer prognosis because it suggests that the cancer is more aggressive and widespread.

 

Option D. Hormonal status: The hormonal status of the tumor (estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) positive or negative) influences both the prognosis and the treatment options. Hormone receptor-positive tumors are often less aggressive and more likely to respond to hormone therapy compared to hormone receptor-negative tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While all these factors are important in assessing the prognosis of breast cancer, the status of the axillary lymph nodes is traditionally considered a key indicator due to its implications for the spread of the disease within the body and potential treatment strategies.

choices.text: Insulinoma; cystic duct, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum
Gastrinoma; CBD, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum
Gastrinoma; cystic duct, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum
Insulinoma; CBD, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum

questions.text: A patient with a history of peptic ulcer shows increased gastrin levels upon pentagastrin stimulation. What is the probable diagnosis and its anatomical boundaries? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gastrinoma; cystic duct, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum


The clinical presentation and elevated gastrin levels indicate Gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome). The anatomical area where gastrinomas are commonly found is called the Triangle of Passaro, which is bounded by:

 

  • Cystic duct superiorly
  • Second and third parts of duodenum medially
  • Head and neck of pancreas forming the third boundary.
  • Most common location within this triangle is the duodenum. 
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by:
    • Elevated fasting serum gastrin
    • Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (SRS) shows 100% positivity

 

 

Other Options:


Option A. Insulinoma; cystic duct, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum: Incorrect. Insulinoma presents with Whipple's triad and hypoglycemia, not elevated gastrin levels.

 

Option B. Gastrinoma; CBD, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum: Incorrect. While gastrinoma is correct, the CBD is not the correct anatomical boundary - it's the cystic duct.

 

Option D. Insulinoma; CBD, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum: Incorrect. Neither the diagnosis (insulinoma) nor the anatomical boundary (CBD) is correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastrinoma occurs within the Triangle of Passaro, bounded by the cystic duct, 2nd and 3rd parts of duodenum, and head/neck of pancreas, with duodenum being the most common location.

 

Gastrinoma

 

  • Malignant
  • Present in triangle of passaro
  • MC site: duodenum (D1)

 

 

Clinical feature: due to hypergastrinemia – Zollinger ellison syndrome

 

  1. Recurrent peptic ulcer
  2. Ulcer at abnormal location
  3. Acid induced diarrhea

questions.text: Which of these is not a component/adjunct of the primary survey in trauma? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CECT

 

Primary survey adjuncts include:

 

  • Chest X-ray
  • Pelvic X-ray
  • eFAST (Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma)
  • ECG
  • Pulse oximetry
  • Arterial blood gas
  • Urinary catheter
  • Nasogastric tube
  • CECT is part of secondary survey, performed only in hemodynamically stable patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chest X-ray:

 

  • Essential adjunct to primary survey
  • Quickly identifies life-threatening conditions like pneumothorax, hemothorax

 

Option B. Pelvic X-ray:

 

  • Important adjunct in primary survey
  • Identifies pelvic fractures which can cause major hemorrhage
  • Guides immediate management decisions

 

Option C. Extended FAST :

 

  • Critical bedside tool in primary survey
  • Rapidly identifies free fluid in abdomen/chest
  • Particularly valuable in unstable patients

 

Educational Objective: 

 

CECT is not a component of primary survey - it belongs to secondary survey and is performed only in hemodynamically stable patients.

choices.text: Secure airway, ICD placement, and IV fluids
Start IV fluids, give atropine and send for chest x-ray
Administer IV Dextrose and send for CT
Evaluate for head injury and perform surgery

questions.text: A patient with a history of chest trauma with breathlessness on examination is found to have systolic BP of 90 mmHg, SpO2 of 85%, GCS 8/15, absent breath sounds. What is the next step? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Secure airway, ICD placement, and IV fluids

 

Following ATLS principles (A, B, C, D):

 

  • GCS 8/15 ("GCS below 8, intubate") indicates need for immediate airway protection
  • SpO2 85% with absent breath sounds suggests respiratory compromise needing ICD
  • BP 90 mmHg indicates a need for fluid resuscitation. This option follows the correct sequence of resuscitation:
    • Airway (A)
    • Breathing (B) - ICD placement
    • Circulation (C) - IV fluids

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Start IV fluids, give atropine and send for chest x-ray:

 

  • Skips airway management in a patient with GCS 8/15
  • Atropine not indicated in this scenario
  • Imaging should not precede resuscitation

 

Option C. Administer IV Dextrose and send for CT:

 

  • Neglects immediate airway and breathing issues
  • CT scan inappropriate before stabilization
  • IV dextrose not indicated in acute trauma

 

Option D. Evaluate for head injury and perform surgery:

 

  • Ignores immediate airway and breathing concerns
  • Surgery evaluation premature before stabilization
  • Violates ATLS principles of prioritization

 

Educational Objective: 


In trauma, follow ABCDE sequence.

questions.text: Earliest/most common symptom of CA esophagus? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dysphagia more to solids

 

In carcinoma esophagus:

 

  • Progressive dysphagia first to solids, then to liquids is the earliest and most common symptom
  • Occurs due to mechanical obstruction from tumor growth
  • Liquids can initially pass through a narrowed lumen
  • Typically presents in elderly smoker males
  • By the time symptoms appear, the disease is usually advanced

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dysphagia more to liquids:

 

  • Characteristic of motility disorders like achalasia
  • In mechanical obstruction, liquids can initially pass-through

 

Option C. Regurgitation:

 

  • Secondary symptom occurring after dysphagia
  • Not the earliest manifestation
  • Occurs when obstruction becomes significant

 

Option D. Lump:

 

  • Rare presentation in esophageal cancer
  • May occur in cervical esophageal tumors
  • Not an early symptom

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Progressive dysphagia, initially more to solids than liquids, is the earliest and most common symptom of carcinoma esophagus.

choices.text: If the hands are visibly soiled
While moving from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care

questions.text: A healthcare worker is performing patient care in a hospital setting. Which of the following is not a correct situation for using hand rub according to standard hand hygiene protocol? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) If the hands are visibly soiled

 

Hand rub, typically alcohol-based hand sanitizer, is not effective when hands are visibly soiled or contaminated with dirt, blood, or other body fluids. In such cases, healthcare workers should wash their hands with soap and water to physically remove the visible contaminants before using hand rub. This is a crucial step to ensure proper hand hygiene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. While moving from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care: Correct. Healthcare workers should use hand rub when transitioning from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care. This helps prevent the spread of pathogens and maintain aseptic conditions. It's an essential practice in infection control

 

Option C. Before donning on gloves: Correct. Hand hygiene, including the use of hand rub, is recommended before putting on gloves. This step ensures that any potential contaminants on the hands are removed before glove use, reducing the risk of contamination during procedures .

 

Option D. During direct patient contact: Correct. Healthcare workers should use hand rub before and after direct patient contact to reduce the risk of transmitting pathogens to or from the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hand hygiene is essential for infection prevention in healthcare settings. Alcohol-based hand rubs are preferred in most cases, but soap and water should be used for visibly soiled hands and in cases of outbreaks of certain pathogens like Clostridium difficile. Hand hygiene should be performed before and after every direct patient contact, before donning gloves, and after removing gloves. Additionally, hand hygiene should be performed while moving from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care. It is important to note that using hand rub is not appropriate if the hands are visibly soiled, as the rub cannot effectively remove dirt and debris from the hands. In such cases, soap and water handwashing is recommended.

choices.text: From the tip of the nose to the ear lobule to the xiphisternum.
From the angle of the mouth to the tragus to the xiphisternum.
From the ala of the nose to the angle of the mandible to the xiphisternum.
From the angle of the mouth to the ear lobule to the umbilicus

questions.text: What is the appropriate technique to measure the placement of a nasogastric tube? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) From the tip of the nose to the ear lobule to the xiphisternum.

 

This is the correct method. The nasogastric tube length is usually measured by estimating the distance from the tip of the nose, past the ear lobule (or the earlobe), and down to the xiphisternum (the point where the sternum meets the costal margin), also known as N-E-X rule. This method ensures that the tube is long enough to pass through the esophagus and reach the stomach without being too long to cause complications or too short to not be effective.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

To determine the appropriate length of a nasogastric tube (also known as Ryle's tube) used for treating intestinal obstruction or providing nutritional support, the NEX method is commonly used, which involves measuring from the tip of the nose to the ear lobule to the xiphisternum. The approximate length to be inserted is around 55 cm. The preferred position for inserting the Ryle's tube is in a sitting position with the neck slightly flexed.

 

The proper positioning of the tube can be confirmed through auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air or by an abdominal radiograph. The ideal placement for an NG tube used for suction is within the stomach to avoid damage to the duodenum. In contrast, an NG feeding tube should be placed post-pyloric to reduce the risk of aspiration.

 

Indications for NG tube usage include gastric decompression in intestinal obstruction, aspiration of gastric fluid, nutritional support, and medication administration. However, some absolute contraindications to NG tube insertion include severe midface trauma and recent nasal surgery.

 

A tray of specialized instruments is used for nasogastric tube insertion, including a lubricating jelly, an NG tube, a syringe, and gloves, among others.

questions.text: Match the following cancers with their corresponding criteria for the minimum number of lymph nodes required for pathological staging: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4

 

The minimum number of lymph nodes required for accurate staging are 16 for stomach carcinoma, 12 for colon carcinoma, 6 for gall bladder carcinoma, and 10 for breast carcinoma.

questions.text: What is the appropriate BIRADS category for a 23-year-old woman with a breast lump, no skin changes, and no indurations, whose histology shows a fibroadenoma appearance? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) BIRADS 2

 

BIRADS 2 is used for benign findings. Given that the histology shows a fibroadenoma appearance, which is a well-recognized benign breast condition, BIRADS 2 is the most suitable category for this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BIRADS 1 or 2: BIRADS 1 is assigned to a category when there is no suspicion of malignancy, and BIRADS 2 is used when there is a benign finding. In this case, since the histology shows a fibroadenoma appearance, which is a benign breast condition, BIRADS 2 is the most appropriate category.

 

Option B. BIRADS 2 or 4: BIRADS 4 is used when there is a suspicious abnormality that may or may not be cancerous. Since the histology in this case indicates a fibroadenoma appearance, which is benign, BIRADS 4 would not be appropriate.

 

Option C. BIRADS 2, 3, or 4: BIRADS 3 is assigned when there is a probably benign finding that requires short-term follow-up. In this case, since the histology indicates a fibroadenoma appearance (a benign finding), BIRADS 3 and BIRADS 4 would not be applicable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of a 23-year-old woman with a breast lump, no skin changes, and no indurations, whose histology shows a fibroadenoma appearance, the appropriate BIRADS category is BIRADS 2.

 

Fibroadenoma is a benign tumor that poses a low risk of malignancy. The Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BIRADS) categories are used to assess the likelihood of malignancy of breast lesions seen on mammograms, ultrasounds, or MRI. Grades 1 and 2 have a very low probability of being malignant, while grade 3 has a slightly higher probability of malignancy.

 

Grades 4 and 5 are considered suspicious and warrant further investigation as they have a higher probability of malignancy.

choices.text: A, B and D are correct

questions.text:
Which of these is/are included as a part of primary survey in trauma? (multiple correct combinations) (INICET MAY 2024)

 

A. Endotracheal intubation
B. Chest X-ray
C. Plain CT
D. ICD insertion
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A, B and D are correct

 

The primary survey in trauma is a critical initial assessment conducted to identify and manage life-threatening conditions. It follows the ABCDE approach (Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, and Exposure). The focus is on stabilizing the patient, and only essential interventions are performed during this phase.

 

Option A. Endotracheal Intubation: This is part of airway management in an unstable trauma patient. If the airway is compromised or there is a risk of airway obstruction, endotracheal (ET) intubation is performed immediately to secure the airway.

 

Option B. Chest X-ray: Although a chest X-ray is considered an adjunct to the primary survey, it is often done bedside in the trauma room as part of the initial assessment of breathing and circulation. It is particularly useful for identifying conditions like pneumothorax, hemothorax, or other thoracic injuries that require immediate attention.

 

Option D. ICD Insertion: Intercostal Drain (ICD) insertion is a bedside procedure that can be part of the primary survey if there is a massive pneumothorax or hemothorax. In cases of tension pneumothorax, an immediate needle decompression is performed, followed by ICD insertion, which is critical for patient survival.

 

Other Option:

 

Option C. Plain CT: This is not included in the primary survey. CT scans are generally reserved for stable patients as they require the patient to be transported to the radiology department, which is not feasible or safe in an unstable trauma patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the primary survey of a trauma patient, life-saving interventions like ET intubation, bedside chest X-ray, and ICD insertion are performed to stabilize the patient. A CT scan is not part of this immediate assessment and is reserved for stable patients.

questions.text: After parotid surgery, the patient is found to have weakness of the lower lip on the ipsilateral side. Which of these injuries is likely to produce this? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cervical branch of facial nerve

 

In this scenario, the patient has undergone parotid surgery and subsequently developed weakness of the lower lip on the same side as the surgery (ipsilateral). This kind of symptom indicates a nerve injury.

 

  • Facial Nerve Branches: The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is responsible for motor control of the muscles of facial expression. It divides into several branches after it exits the stylomastoid foramen, including the temporal, zygomatic, buccal, mandibular (marginal mandibular), and cervical branches.
  • Cervical Branch: The cervical branch of the facial nerve, along with the marginal mandibular branch, supplies the muscles of the lower face, including those involved in the movement of the lower lip. An injury to the cervical branch could result in weakness of the lower lip, which is consistent with the patient's presentation.
  • Marginal Mandibular Branch: Although the marginal mandibular branch is primarily responsible for the lower lip, in cases where this specific branch is not listed as an option, the cervical branch is the closest and most accurate choice because it is part of the lower division of the facial nerve that supplies the lower lip muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Main trunk of the facial nerve: Injury to the main trunk of the facial nerve would likely cause more extensive symptoms, including the inability to close the eye (Bell's phenomenon), loss of forehead wrinkling, and other signs of lower motor neuron facial paralysis, which are not mentioned in this case. Therefore, this option is less likely.

 

Option B. Temporal branch of the facial nerve: The temporal branch of the facial nerve innervates muscles in the upper face, such as those involved in raising the eyebrows and closing the eyelids. It does not affect the lower lip, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Parotid duct: Injury to the parotid duct would result in issues related to salivation, such as a salivary fistula, but it would not cause motor weakness of the lower lip. This option is also incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Weakness of the lower lip after parotid surgery is most likely due to injury to the cervical branch of the facial nerve. The marginal mandibular branch is the most specific, but if not listed, the cervical branch is the closest correct option

choices.text: Transurethral resection of the bladder tumour

questions.text: An adult male patient in his 60s presented to the outpatient department with a complaint of haematuria. Upon examination, a 2x2 cm bladder mass was observed, which was diagnosed as a low-grade transitional cell carcinoma. What is the recommended course of action for this patient? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transurethral resection of the bladder tumour

 

For this patient diagnosed with bladder carcinoma, transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT) is the most beneficial treatment option among the given choices. Based on the available evidence, there is no indication of muscle invasion or advanced cancer, suggesting that the most probable pathological stage is pTa - low grade non-muscle invasive cancer, for which TURBT followed by intravesical chemotherapy is the recommended treatment. TURBT is performed to pathologically stage the tumor and determine the appropriate course of treatment. Intravesical therapy using chemotherapy or immunotherapy is administered after TURBT to eradicate any residual cancer cells in the bladder lining, but it is not effective against cancers that have spread to muscle layers.

 

This is the correct answer. TURBT is a standard initial procedure for diagnosing and treating visible tumors, especially for low-grade, noninvasive disease. It involves removing the tumor from the bladder wall via the urethra. The stage of the bladder cancer can be determined by examining the sample removed during a TURBT, which aids in further treatment decisions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Resection with ileal conduit: This is a more invasive surgery typically used for muscle invasive bladder cancers (radical cystectomy). An ileal conduit is a urinary diversion technique where urine is redirected through a piece of the intestine and out to a stoma on the abdomen.

 

Option C. Partial cystectomy with bladder reconstruction: This involves removing a part of the bladder affected by cancer. It's reserved for select patients where the tumor is localized and not near the urethral or ureteral openings. It might not be the first line of treatment for a 2x2 cm low-grade tumor.

 

Option D. Neo-adjuvant chemotherapy: This refers to chemotherapy given before a primary treatment in advanced cancers. In the case of bladder cancer, neo-adjuvant chemotherapy might be used before a surgery to shrink the tumor size or improve outcomes. However, for a low-grade, small tumor, it is not typically the first line of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-muscle invasive bladder tumors (pTa/pT1): TUR-BT + Intravesical chemotherapy

 

Muscle invasive (pT2/pT3 and some pT4): Radical cystectomy + Ileal conduit

questions.text: Which vaccine is not recommended to be given before splenectomy in a 5-year-old child with hereditary spherocytosis and hypersplenism? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Typhoid vaccine

 

The typhoid vaccine is typically not recommended before splenectomy in a child with hereditary spherocytosis and hypersplenism. Typhoid vaccination may lead to a transient decrease in platelet count, which can exacerbate the existing hypersplenism and increase the risk of bleeding. Therefore, it is often deferred until after splenectomy when the risk of post-vaccination thrombocytopenia is reduced.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumococcal vaccine: The pneumococcal vaccine is recommended for individuals with asplenia (absence of the spleen) or hyposplenism (reduced spleen function) because they are at an increased risk of severe infections, including those caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae. However, for individuals with hereditary spherocytosis who have an intact spleen, the pneumococcal vaccine may be administered as part of routine immunization.

 

Option C. Haemophilus influenza B vaccine: The Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) vaccine is recommended as part of routine childhood immunization and does not have specific contraindications related to hereditary spherocytosis or splenectomy.

 

Option D. Meningococcal vaccine: The meningococcal vaccine is recommended for individuals with asplenia or hyposplenism, as they are at an increased risk of meningococcal infections. However, for individuals with hereditary spherocytosis who have an intact spleen, the meningococcal vaccine may be administered as part of routine immunization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Typhoid vaccine is often deferred in children with hereditary spherocytosis and hypersplenism before splenectomy due to the risk of transiently reduced platelet count, which can be problematic in the presence of hypersplenism. Other vaccines, such as the pneumococcal, Haemophilus influenzae B, and meningococcal vaccines, may be administered based on routine immunization recommendations and the individual's spleen status.

questions.text: The leading cause of bladder outlet obstruction in male children is: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior urethral valve

 

This is the most common cause of lower urinary tract obstruction in male infants. PUV is a congenital malformation found only in boys where there is an abnormal fold of tissue in the posterior urethra, preventing normal urine outflow and leading to bladder outlet obstruction. The condition can lead to hydronephrosis if not treated promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urethral atresia: This is a rare congenital anomaly where a segment of the urethra fails to canalize or develop. It leads to complete obstruction of the urethra, and while it does cause bladder outlet obstruction, it is less common than PUV in male children.

 

Option C. Anterior urethral valve: This is a rare congenital anomaly and is much less common than the posterior urethral valve. While it can cause obstruction, its prevalence and significance in causing bladder outlet obstruction in male children are far less than that of PUV.

 

Option D. Ureterocele: A ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the terminal ureter within the bladder. It can cause obstruction of the ureter itself. They are not the leading cause in male children when compared to PUV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most frequent cause of bladder outflow obstruction in male children is the posterior urethral valve (PUV).
  • PUV is a membranous fold located in the posterior urethra, typically found just distal to the verumontanum. It is thought to occur due to the persistence of the urogenital membrane.
  • Urethral obstruction can cause dilation of the posterior urethral valve, bladder, and bilateral hydronephrosis, leading to a keyhole sign on prenatal ultrasound and potentially oligohydramnios.
  • If not detected prenatally, PUV may present postnatally as a newborn or young infant with urinary tract symptoms, abdominal distension or and recurrent UTIs.
  • Left untreated, PUV may result in chronic kidney disease, bladder dysfunction, and vesicoureteral reflux.
  • Diagnosis of PUV is typically based on the presence of an elongated posterior valve during the voiding phase of the voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG).

questions.text: Calculate for Burn Surface Area (BSA) for a patent with burn involving the chest and abdomen right arm and right thigh (circumferental): (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 31.5% 

 

According to the ‘Rule of Nine’, BSA is calculated as: 

 

  • Chest and Abdomen = 18%
  • Right Arm (not entire upper limb) = 4.5%
  • Right Thigh = 9%

 

Total = 18% + 4.5% + 9% = 31.5%

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Rule of Nines is a method used to estimate the total body surface area affected by burns. It divides the body into sections that represent approximately 9% of the total surface area, facilitating quick and effective assessment and treatment planning for burn patients.

choices.text: Ileocolic, right colic and branch of middle colic
Ileocolic, right colic, stem of middle colic, left colic
Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient has been diagnosed with proximal transverse colon carcinoma. The physician recommends an extended right colectomy as a treatment option. Which arteries should be resected during an extended right colectomy to prevent the spread of cancer in proximal transverse colon carcinoma? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic.

 

During an extended right colectomy, the ileocolic, right colic, and trunk of the middle colic vessels are typically resected to prevent the spread of cancer in proximal transverse colon carcinoma.

 

The stem of the middle colic and the left colic artery are not resected during an extended right colectomy as they are not directly involved with the blood supply to the proximal transverse colon. It is important to note that the surgical management of colon cancer depends on the stage and location of the tumor and may involve various surgical techniques, including colectomy and lymphadenectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of radical colectomies and vessels ligated:

 

  1. Right hemicolectomy: Ileocolic, right colic and right branch of middle colic artery
  2. Extended right hemicolectomy: Ileocolic, right colic and stem/origin of middle colic artery
  3. Left hemicolectomy: Left colic and sigmoid artery

questions.text: A young female presents with pain in lower abdomen and vomiting in the ER. Clinical examination reveals a swelling, lateral and below the public tubercle. X-ray show intestinal obstruction. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strangulated femoral hernia

 

This type of hernia occurs just below the inguinal ligament, where the abdominal contents protrude through the femoral canal. It is more common in women, especially those with repeated pregnancies. The description of the swelling's location lateral and below the pubic tubercle fits well with a femoral hernia. If the hernia becomes strangulated, it means that the blood supply to the herniated tissue is compromised, leading to severe pain, vomiting, and signs of intestinal obstruction as seen on X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adhesions: Bands of fibrous tissue that can form between abdominal tissues and organs, often as a result of surgery can lead to intestinal obstruction if they cause the intestines to twist or kink. However, adhesions themselves do not cause noticeable swelling as described in the scenario.

 

Option B. Strangulated inguinal hernia: This will present with a swelling above the pubic tubercle.

 

Option D. Appendicular mass: This refers to a mass formed from a swollen, inflamed appendix often associated with appendicitis. While this can lead to pain and vomiting, the location of the pain and swelling typically would be around the lower right quadrant of the abdomen, not below the pubic tubercle.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Given the location of the swelling and the associated symptoms, the most probable diagnosis is a Strangulated Femoral Hernia. This condition requires prompt surgical intervention to relieve the obstruction and restore blood flow to the entrapped tissues to prevent further complications such as tissue necrosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department with multiple stab injuries to the chest. On examination, there is reduced chest movement on the right side and tracheal deviation to the left side. Additionally, the neck veins are distended. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Needle thoracocentesis

 

Patient with stab to chest with reduced chest movement on right, mediastinal shift to left with distended neck veins is suffering from tension pneumothorax. Next step is placement of wide bore needle in triangle of safety to decompress the pneumothorax, followed by ICD insertion.

 

This is the correct answer. Needle thoracocentesis is the next best step in the management of the patient with tension pneumothorax. It is a procedure that involves inserting a needle into the pleural space to aspirate the air or fluid. It is performed initially to decompress the tension pneumothorax in the triangle of safety (between Pect. Major anteriorly, Latissimus dorsi posteriorly, 5th intercostal space inferiorly).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emergency room thoracotomy: This is not the next best step in the management of the patient with tension pneumothorax. Resuscitative thoracotomy is an emergency surgical procedure that is performed in the presence of cardiac arrest due to penetrating chest trauma.

 

Option B. ICD placement: This is not the next best step in the management of the patient with tension pneumothorax. An ICD (intercostal drainage) is a tube inserted into the pleural space to drain the air or fluid. ICD placement is the definitive management of tension pneumothorax but is not the next step in the management.

 

Option D. Finger thoracotomy: This is not the next best step in the management of the patient with tension pneumothorax. Finger thoracotomy is an alternative approach when needle decompression fails or is not possible. It involves making a small incision in the chest wall and using the finger to manually decompress the pneumothorax. However, needle decompression should be attempted first before considering finger thoracostomy.

choices.text: Laparoscopic surgeries result in lesser post-operative pain.
Laparoscopic surgeries are cosmetically better as they result in smaller incisions.
Laparoscopic surgeries result in an earlier return to normal physiological function.
Laparoscopic surgeries result in a longer duration of stay in the hospital

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient is scheduled for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which of the following is not an advantage of laparoscopic surgery? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laparoscopic surgeries result in a longer duration of stay in the hospital

 

Laparoscopic surgeries have become popular as they result in lesser post-operative pain, are cosmetically better, and result in an earlier return to normal physiological function (Options A, B, and C). Patients are discharged from the hospital earlier, with a lower incidence of complications, as compared to open surgeries. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer, as it is not an advantage of laparoscopic surgery.

 

This statement is incorrect. Laparoscopic surgery is associated with shorter hospital stays compared to traditional open surgery. Patients typically spend less time in the hospital and recover faster, which is one of the key advantages of this approach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laparoscopic surgeries result in lesser post-operative pain: Smaller incisions and less tissue trauma typically result in less post-operative pain compared to traditional open surgery.

 

Option B. Laparoscopic surgeries are cosmetically better as they result in smaller incisions: This is an advantage of laparoscopic surgery. The smaller incisions are not only cosmetically appealing but also result in reduced scarring and a lower risk of wound infections.

 

Option C. Laparoscopic surgeries result in an earlier return to normal physiological function: Patients often recover more quickly and can resume their normal activities sooner due to the minimally invasive nature of the procedure.

questions.text: A patient with oral cancer as shown. What is the T stage? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) T4a

 

Based on TNM staging for oral cancer:

 

  • Invasion of the floor of the mouth is considered T4a as per AJCC staging
  • Tumor invading floor of mouth indicates local invasion

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T2:

 

  • T2 represents tumor 2-4 cm without deep invasion
  • Does not account for floor-of-mouth involvement

 

Option B. T3:

 

  • T3 represents tumor >4 cm without deep invasion
  • Does not account for local invasion

 

Option D. T4b:

 

  • Represents very advanced local disease
  • Involves masticator space, pterygoid plates, skull base
  • Involves encasement of internal carotid artery
  • These structures not involved in this case

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Invasion of floor of mouth in oral cancer represents T4a disease, indicating moderately advanced but resectable local disease.
